TitleBlock.Title: Charge on certain high value disposals by companies etc

P1para.Text: TCGA 1992 is amended as follows.

P2para.Text: Section 1 (the charge to tax) is amended as follows.
In subsection (2), after “Acts” insert “, subject to the exception in subsection (2A)”.
After subsection (2) insert—

But companies are chargeable to capital gains tax, and not corporation tax, in respect of chargeable gains accruing to them to the extent that those gains are ATED-related gains in respect of which the companies are chargeable to capital gains tax under section 2B.
In subsection (3) for “subsection (2)” substitute “subsections (2) and (2A)”.

P1para.Text: In section 2 (persons and gains chargeable to capital gains tax, and allowable losses), after subsection (7) insert—

P2para.Text: Nothing in this section applies in relation to an ATED-related gain chargeable to, or an ATED-related loss allowable for the purposes of, capital gains tax by virtue of section 2B.

P1para.Text: After section 2 insert—

P1group.Title: Persons chargeable to capital gains tax on ATED-related gains

P2para.Text: A person (other than an excluded person) (“P”) is chargeable to capital gains tax in respect of any ATED-related chargeable gain accruing to P in a tax year on a relevant high value disposal.
A person is “excluded” if the person is an individual, the trustees of a settlement or the personal representatives of a deceased person and—

P3para.Text: the gain accrues on a disposal of any partnership assets and the person is a member of the partnership, or
the gain accrues on a disposal of any property held for the purposes of a relevant collective investment scheme and the person is a participant in relation to the scheme.

P2para.Text: Capital gains tax is charged on the total amount of ATED-related chargeable gains accruing to P in the tax year on relevant high value disposals, after deducting ring-fenced ATED-related allowable losses in relation to that year.
Subsections (5) to (7) apply in relation to an ATED-related allowable loss accruing to P in a tax year on a relevant high value disposal.
The loss is not allowable as a deduction from ATED-related chargeable gains accruing in any earlier tax year on relevant high value disposals.
Relief is not to be given under this Act more than once in respect of the loss or any part of the loss.
Relief is not to be given under this Act in respect of the loss if, and so far as, relief has been or may be given in respect of it under the Tax Acts.
The only deductions which can be made from ATED-related chargeable gains are those permitted by this section.
See section 57A and Schedule 4ZZA for how to compute—

P3para.Text: the ATED-related gain or loss accruing on a relevant high value disposal, and
the gain or loss accruing on a relevant high value disposal which is not ATED-related.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “participant”, in relation to a relevant collective investment scheme, is to be read in accordance with section 235 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000;
“relevant collective investment scheme” means a collective investment scheme within the meaning of Part 17 of that Act (see section 235 of that Act) other than—
a unit trust scheme within the meaning of that Part (see section 237(1) of that Act), or
an open-ended investment company within the meaning of that Part (see section 236(1) of that Act);
“ring-fenced ATED-related allowable losses”, in relation to a tax year, means—
any ATED-related allowable losses accruing to P in the tax year on relevant high value disposals, and

so far as they have not been allowed as a deduction from ATED-related chargeable gains accruing in any previous tax year on relevant high value disposals, any ATED-related allowable losses accruing to P in any previous tax year (not earlier than the tax year 2013-14) on such disposals.

P2para.Text: A disposal on which a gain or loss accrues to P is a “relevant high value disposal” if conditions A to D are met.
Condition A is that the disposal is of the whole or part of a chargeable interest (“the disposed of interest”).
Condition B is that the disposed of interest has, at any time during the relevant ownership period, been or formed part of a single-dwelling interest.
Condition C is that—

P3para.Text: P, or
if the disposed of interest is a partnership asset, the responsible partners, or
if the disposed of interest is held for the purposes of a relevant collective investment scheme, the person who has day-to-day control over the management of the property subject to the scheme,

P2para.Text: has or have been within the charge to annual tax on enveloped dwellings with respect to that single-dwelling interest on one or more days in the relevant ownership period which are not relievable days in relation to the interest.
Condition D is that the amount or value of the consideration for the disposal exceeds the threshold amount (see section 2D).
In this section and section 2D—

Para.Text: “chargeable interest” has the same meaning as in Part 3 of the Finance Act 2013 (annual tax on enveloped dwellings) (see section 104 of that Act (chargeable interest));
“dwelling” has the same meaning as in that Part (see section 110of that Act);
“relevant collective investment scheme” has the same meaning as in section 2B;
“the relevant ownership period” means the period which begins—
if an election has been made under paragraph 5 of Schedule 4ZZA, with the day on which P acquired the chargeable interest or, if later, 31 March 1982, and
in any other case, with the day on which P acquired the chargeable interest or, if later, 6 April 2013,
and ends with the day before the day on which the disposal occurs;

“relievable day” means a day which is “relievable” by virtue of any of the provisions mentioned in section 130 of the Finance Act 2013 (ATED: effect of reliefs) and in respect of which a claim has been made under section 103(3) of that Act;
“the responsible partners” has the same meaning as in section 93 of that Act;
“single-dwelling interest” has the same meaning as in Part 3 of that Act;

P2para.Text: and a reference to being “within the charge” to annual tax on enveloped dwellings with respect to a single-dwelling interest is to be read in accordance with section 168(2) of that Act.
For the purposes of Condition C—

P3para.Text: Part 3 of the Finance Act 2013 applies, in relation to any part of the relevant ownership period falling before 1 April 2013, as if section 91(8)(a) of that Act (first chargeable period for ATED) read “the period beginning with 31 March 1982 and ending with 31 March 1983”, and

when determining whether any day falling before 1 April 2013 is a relievable day, the definition of “relievable day” in subsection (6) above is to read as if the words “and in respect of which a claim has been made under section 103(3) of that Act” were omitted.

P2para.Text: This section applies to determine “the threshold amount” in relation to a disposal which meets Conditions A to C in section 2C (“the current disposal”).
If—

P3para.Text: the current disposal is not a part disposal of an asset, and
P has not made any relevant related disposals,

P2para.Text: the threshold amount is £2 million, subject to subsection (5) (joint interests).
If paragraphs (a) and (b) of subsection (2) do not both apply, the threshold amount is the relevant fraction of £2 million, subject to subsection (5) (joint interests).
“The relevant fraction” is—

Para.Text: where—
“C” is the amount or value of the consideration for the current disposal;
“TMV” is what would be the market value, at the time of the current disposal, of a notional asset comprising—
the disposed of interest (see section 2C(2)),
if the current disposal is a part disposal, any part of the chargeable interest held by P that remains undisposed of immediately following that part disposal,
any chargeable interest (or part of a chargeable interest) which was the subject of a relevant related disposal, and

any chargeable interest (or part of a chargeable interest) held by P at the time of the current disposal which, if P had disposed of it at that time, would have been the subject of a relevant related disposal.

P2para.Text: If the disposed of interest is a share of the whole of—

P3para.Text: a chargeable interest, or
a part of a chargeable interest,

P2para.Text: subsections (2) and (3) have effect as if the references to “£2 million” were to the joint share fraction of that amount.
The joint share fraction is the fraction of the whole of the chargeable interest or part represented by the disposed of interest.
“Relevant related disposal”, in relation to the current disposal, means any disposal by P which—

P3para.Text: meets Conditions A to C in section 2C in circumstances where the single-dwelling interest referred to in Condition C is—

P4para.Text: the single-dwelling interest by virtue of which Condition C is met in relation to the current disposal, or
another single-dwelling interest in the same dwelling as that interest, and

P3para.Text: was made in the period of 6 years ending with the day on which the current disposal occurs, but not before 6 April 2013.

P2para.Text: This section applies where (ignoring this section)—

P3para.Text: a disposal would be a relevant high value disposal, but for a failure to meet condition D in section 2C,
if it were a relevant high value disposal, an ATED-related loss would accrue to a person (other than an excluded person) in a tax year on the disposal, and
the total of the sums allowable as a deduction under section 38 in relation to the disposal exceeds the threshold amount in relation to the disposal.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this Act—

P3para.Text: the disposal is to be treated as a relevant high value disposal (and section 57A and Schedule 4ZZA apply accordingly), and

the ATED-related loss which accrues on the disposal is to be restricted to the amount which would have been that loss had the consideration for the disposal been £1 greater than the threshold amount in relation to the disposal.

P2para.Text: In a case where paragraph 2 of Schedule 4ZZA applies (calculation of gains or losses on disposals of assets held on 5 April 2013), the reference in subsection (1)(c) to the disposal is to be read as a reference to the notional disposal referred to in paragraph 3(2) of that Schedule (disposal on which notional post-April 2013 gain or loss accrues).
Nothing in subsection (2)(b) restricts any loss which is not ATED-related, or affects any gain (whether or not ATED-related), accruing on the relevant high value disposal.
In this section—

Para.Text: “excluded” has the meaning given by section 2B(2);
“the threshold amount” has the meaning given by section 2D.

P2para.Text: This section applies to an ATED-related gain which accrues on a relevant high value disposal and is chargeable to capital gains tax by virtue of section 2B.
There is excluded from the gain so much of it as exceeds five-thirds of the difference between—

P3para.Text: the amount or value of the consideration, and
the threshold amount (within the meaning of section 2D) in relation to the disposal.

P2para.Text: But where the relevant fraction is less than 1, subsection (2) has effect as if the amount determined under that subsection were the relevant fraction of that amount.
“The relevant fraction”—

P3para.Text: in a case where the ATED-related gain is determined in accordance with paragraph 3 of Schedule 4ZZA, has the meaning given by paragraph 3(4) of that Schedule, and
in a case where the ATED-related gain is determined in accordance with paragraph 6 of that Schedule, has the same meaning as in paragraph 6(5)(a) of that Schedule.

P2para.Text: Nothing in this section restricts any gain which is not ATED-related, or affects any loss (whether or not ATED-related), accruing on the relevant high value disposal.

P2para.Text: The rate of capital gains tax in respect of gains chargeable under section 2B accruing to a person in a tax year is 28%.

P2para.Text: Nothing in this section applies in relation to an ATED-related gain chargeable to, or an ATED-related loss allowable for the purposes of, capital gains tax by virtue of section 2B.

P1para.Text: In section 13 (attribution of gains to members of non-resident companies), after subsection (1) insert—

P2para.Text: But this section does not apply if the gain is an ATED-related gain chargeable to capital gains tax by virtue of section 2B (capital gains tax on ATED-related gains).

P1para.Text: In section 16 (computation of losses), in subsection (3) after “section” insert “2B,”.
In Part 2, after Chapter 4 insert—

Chapter.Title: Computation of gains and losses: relevant high value disposals

P1group.Title: Gains and losses on relevant high value disposals

P2para.Text: Schedule 4ZZA makes provision about the computation of gains and losses on relevant high value disposals, including provision about whether a gain or loss is ATED-related or not.

But if the effect of Schedule 4ZZA applying in relation to a disposal would be that no ATED-related gain or loss accrues on the disposal, for the purposes of this Act the gain or loss on the disposal is to be computed ignoring that Schedule (and is not ATED-related).

P1para.Text: After section 100 insert—

In this section—

Para.Text: “EEA UCITS” has the same meaning as in Part 17 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (see section 237 of that Act);
“unit trust scheme” has same meaning as in that Part (see section 237(1) of that Act);
“open-ended investment company” has the same meaning as in that Part (see section 236(1) of that Act).

After subsection (3) insert—
But if the person—

P3para.Text: meets the requirement of paragraph (a) or (b) of subsection (3), and

(ignoring any election under this section) would be treated under subsection (1) as making a relevant high value disposal on which an ATED-related gain chargeable to, or loss allowable for the purposes of, capital gains tax under section 2B would accrue,

P2para.Text: the person may not elect under subsection (3) but may elect for subsection (3ZB) to apply.
Subject to subsection (4), where an election is made for this subsection to apply—

P3para.Text: a gain or loss accruing on the disposal under subsection (1) which is not ATED-related is not a chargeable gain or an allowable loss,

the market value of the asset at the time of the appropriation is, for the purposes of computing the profits of the trade for the purposes of tax, to be treated as reduced by the amount of any gain, or increased by the amount of any loss, which would be a chargeable gain or allowable loss but for paragraph (a), and
the chargeable gain or allowable loss which accrues on that disposal and is ATED-related is unaffected by the election.

P2para.Text: In subsection (3A), after “subsection (3)” insert “or (3ZA)”.
In subsection (4), after “subsection (3)” insert “or (3ZA)”.

P1para.Text: In section 171 (transfers within a group: general provisions), in subsection (2), after paragraph (b) insert—

P3para.Text: a relevant high value disposal on which (ignoring subsection (1)) there accrues to company A an ATED-related gain chargeable to, or an ATED-related loss allowable for the purposes of, capital gains tax by virtue of section 2B; or

P1para.Text: After section 187 insert—

P1group.Title: Deemed disposal under section 185: ATED-related gains and losses

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: (ignoring subsections (2) and (3)) a gain or loss would accrue to a company on a disposal of an asset deemed to have been made by virtue of section 185(2), and
that gain or loss is an ATED-related gain chargeable to, or an ATED-related loss allowable for the purposes of, capital gains tax under section 2B.

P2para.Text: That gain or loss does not accrue to the company on that disposal.
But, on a subsequent disposal of the whole or part of the asset, the whole or a corresponding part of the gain or loss—

P3para.Text: is deemed to accrue to the company (in addition to any gain or loss that actually accrues on that subsequent disposal), and
(if that would not otherwise be the case) is to be treated as an ATED-related gain or loss accruing on a relevant high value disposal.

P2para.Text: Nothing in this section affects the treatment, for the purposes of this Act, of any gain or loss which is not ATED-related and accrues on the disposal of the asset deemed to have been made by virtue of section 185(2).

P1para.Text: In section 271 (miscellaneous exemptions)—

P3para.Text: in subsection (1A), after “registered pension scheme” insert “or an overseas pension scheme”, and
in subsection (10), for the words after “above” substitute “—

Para.Text: “investments” includes futures contracts and options contracts;
“overseas pension scheme” has the same meaning as in Part 4 of the Finance Act 2004 (see section 150(7) of that Act).”

P1para.Text: In section 288 (interpretation), in subsection (1), at the appropriate places insert—

Para.Text: “ATED-related”, in relation to a gain or loss, is to be construed in accordance with section 57A and Schedule 4ZZA;”;
““relevant high value disposal” has the meaning given by section 2C;

P1para.Text: After Schedule 4 insert—

TitleBlock.Title: relevant high value disposals: gains and losses

P1para.Text: This Schedule applies for the purposes of determining in relation to a relevant high value disposal made by a person (“P”)—

P3para.Text: whether a gain or loss which is ATED-related accrues to P on the disposal, and
whether a gain or loss which is not ATED-related accrues to P on the disposal.

P1group.Title: Assets held on 5 April 2013: no paragraph 5 election

P1para.Text: If the interest disposed of was held by P on 5 April 2013—

P3para.Text: paragraph 3 applies for the purposes of computing the gain or loss accruing to P which is ATED-related, and
paragraph 4 applies for the purposes of computing the gain or loss accruing to P which is not ATED-related.

P2para.Text: An amount equal to the relevant fraction of the notional post-April 2013 gain or loss is the ATED-related gain or loss (as the case may be).

“Notional post-April 2013 gain or loss” means the gain or loss which (in the absence of section 2B and this Schedule) would have accrued on the relevant high value disposal had P acquired the interest on 5 April 2013 for a consideration equal to its market value on that date.

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (2), the amount of the gain or loss accruing to P is to be computed (whether or not that would otherwise be the case) as if P were within the charge to capital gains tax (but not within the charge to corporation tax on chargeable gains).
“The relevant fraction” is—

Para.Text: where—

P2para.Text: “CD” is the number of days in the relevant ownership period which are ATED chargeable days;
“The relevant ownership period” means the period beginning with 6 April 2013 and ending with the day before the day on which the relevant high value disposal occurs.
“ATED chargeable day” means any day by virtue of which condition C in section 2C(4) is met in relation to the relevant high value disposal.
The gain or loss accruing on the relevant high value disposal which is not ATED-related is computed as follows.
Determine the amount of the notional pre-April 2013 gain or loss.
In a case where there is a notional post-April 2013 gain—

Para.Text: (a) determine the amount of that gain remaining after the deduction of the ATED-related gain determined under paragraph 3, and
(b) adjust that remaining gain by reducing it by the notional indexation allowance.

P2para.Text: In a case where there is a notional post-April 2013 loss, determine the amount of that loss remaining after deduction of the ATED-related loss determined under paragraph 3.
Add—

Para.Text: (a)the amount of any gain or loss determined under Step 1, and
(b)the amount of any adjusted gain determined under Step 2 or (as the case may be) any loss determined under Step 3,

P2para.Text: (treating any amount which is a loss as a negative amount).
If the result is a positive amount, that amount is the gain on the relevant high value disposal which is not ATED-related.

“The notional pre-April 2013 gain or loss” means the gain or loss which would have accrued on 5 April 2013 had the interest been disposed of for a consideration equal to its market value on that date.

For the purposes of sub-paragraph (2), the amount of the gain or loss accruing to P is to be computed (whether or not that would otherwise be the case) as if P were within the charge to corporation tax on chargeable gains (but not within the charge to capital gains tax).
Paragraph 3(2) and (3) (meaning of “notional post-April 2013 gain or loss”) also applies for the purposes of this paragraph.
“Notional indexation allowance” means the relevant fraction of an amount equal to the difference between—

P3para.Text: the indexation allowance which (in the absence of section 2B and this Schedule) would be made under Chapter 4 of Part 2 in determining the gain accruing on the relevant high value disposal were that gain being computed for corporation tax purposes, and
the indexation allowance which is made under Chapter 4 of Part 2 in determining the notional pre-April 2013 gain.

P2para.Text: “The relevant fraction” is—

Para.Text: where “CD” and “TD” have the same meaning as in paragraph 3(4).

P1group.Title: Election for paragraph 2 to 4 not to apply to a chargeable interest

P2para.Text: A person may make an election under this paragraph for paragraphs 2 to 4 not to apply in relation to a chargeable interest held by (or any part of which is held by) the person on 5 April 2013.
An election is irrevocable.

An election must be made by being included in a tax return under the Management Act for the tax year in which the first relevant high value disposal by the person of the chargeable interest (or any part of it) on or after 6 April 2013 occurs.
The reference in sub-paragraph (3) to an election being included in a return includes an election being included by virtue of an amendment of the return.
All such adjustments are to be made, whether by way of discharge or repayment of tax, the making of assessments or otherwise, as are required to give effect to an election.
In this paragraph “chargeable interest” has the same meaning as in Part 3 of the Finance Act 2013 (annual tax on enveloped dwellings) (see section 104 of that Act).

P1group.Title: Cases where election made or assets acquired after 5 April 2013

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: an election is made by P under paragraph 5 in respect of the chargeable interest which (or a part of which) is the subject of the relevant high value disposal, or
the chargeable interest (or part) disposed of by the relevant high value disposal was not held by P throughout the period beginning with 5 April 2013 and ending with the disposal.

P2para.Text: The ATED-related gain or loss accruing on the relevant high value disposal is computed as follows.
Determine the amount of the gain or loss which would accrue to P, ignoring section 2B and this Schedule (but not the remainder of this Step).

For this purpose, the amount of the gain or loss is to be computed (whether or not that would otherwise be the case) as if P were within the charge to capital gains tax (but not within the charge to corporation tax on chargeable gains).
The gain or loss accruing on the relevant high value disposal which is not ATED-related is to be computed as follows.
In a case where there is a gain under Step 1 of sub-paragraph (2)—

Para.Text: (a) determine the amount of the gain remaining after the deduction of the ATED-related gain, and
(b) adjust the remaining gain by reducing it by an amount equal to the notional indexation allowance.

P2para.Text: That adjusted gain is the gain accruing on the relevant high value disposal which is not ATED-related.
In a case where there is a loss under Step 1 of sub-paragraph (2), determine the amount of the loss remaining after deduction of the ATED-related loss.

“Notional indexation allowance” means the relevant fraction of the indexation allowance which would be made under Chapter 4 of Part 2 in determining the gain under Step 1 in sub-paragraph (2) were that gain being computed for corporation tax purposes.
Subject to sub-paragraph (6), “the relevant fraction”—

P3para.Text: in sub-paragraph (2) has the same meaning as in paragraph 3(4), and
in sub-paragraph (4) has the same meaning as in paragraph 4(6).

P2para.Text: For the purpose of determining the relevant fraction under sub-paragraph (5), paragraph 3(5) has effect as if the relevant ownership period began on the day on which P acquired the interest or, if later, 31 March 1982.

This paragraph applies where, as a result of a claim under section 103(3) of the Finance Act 2013 (adjustment of chargeable amount), or an amendment of or adjustment to such a claim, there is an alteration in the number of ATED chargeable days.

All such adjustments are to be made, whether by way of discharge or repayment of tax, the making of assessments or otherwise, as are required to give effect to any change in liability to tax as a result of that alteration.

P1para.Text: In Schedule 7A (restriction on set-off of pre-entry losses), after paragraph 10 insert—
Section 161(3ZB)(a) and (b) does not apply to a loss if, in the absence of an election under section 161(3ZA), the loss would have been a pre-entry loss.

the amount (“C”) which is equal to 5% of the invested amount in respect of the former investment for tax year X,

P2para.Text: “A” is to be reduced by multiplying it by the fraction—

TitleBlock.Title: Manufactured payments

P1para.Text: Before Part 11A of ITA 2007 insert—

P2para.Text: This Part deals with the application of the Income Tax Acts to manufactured payment relationships and payments representative of dividends or interest.
For the purposes of the Income Tax Acts a person has a manufactured payment relationship if conditions A to C are met.
Condition A is that under any arrangements—

P3para.Text: an amount is payable by or to the person, or
any other benefit is given by or to the person (including the release of the whole or part of any liability to pay an amount).

P2para.Text: Condition B is that the arrangements relate to the transfer of securities.
Condition C is that the amount or value of the other benefit—

P3para.Text: is representative of a dividend or interest on the securities, or
will fall to be treated as representative of such a dividend or interest when it is paid or given.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) the reference to an amount being payable, or other benefit being given, by the person includes a reference to an amount being payable, or other benefit being given, by another person on behalf of the person in question.
In this Part—

Para.Text: “manufactured payment”, in relation to a manufactured payment relationship, means an amount, or the value of a benefit, within subsection (2), and
“securities” means—
shares in a company, and

loan stock or any similar security (whether the security is of the government of the United Kingdom, any other government, any public or local authority in the United Kingdom or elsewhere, or any other company or body).

P1group.Title: Treatment of payer of manufactured payment

P2para.Text: This section applies where a person has a manufactured payment relationship under which a manufactured payment is paid by or on behalf of the person.
No deduction is allowed in respect of the manufactured payment in calculating any profits or other income of the person for income tax purposes (subject to subsection (3)).

Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the person so far as the manufactured payment is brought into account under Part 2 of ITTOIA 2005 in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the person.
But nothing in subsection (3) affects the question whether (apart from that provision) a deduction in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the person is allowed.

P1group.Title: Treatment of recipient of manufactured payment

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) applies if a person has a manufactured payment relationship under which a manufactured payment is payable to the person.

For the purposes of the charge to income tax on the person’s income, the Income Tax Acts apply to the person as if the manufactured payment were a dividend or interest on the securities (as the case may require).
Subsection (2) is subject to subsections (4) to (6).

Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the person so far as the manufactured payment is brought into account under Part 2 of ITTOIA 2005 in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the person.
Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the person for the purposes of determining entitlement to double taxation relief in respect of any dividend or interest.

In a case in which the manufactured payment is treated as a dividend by virtue of subsection (2), the person is not entitled to a tax credit under Chapter 3 of Part 4 of ITTOIA 2005 (tax credits for certain recipients of distributions) in respect of the dividend.
For the purposes of this section “double taxation relief” means any relief given under or as a result of Part 2 of TIOPA 2010.

P1para.Text: Before Part 18 of CTA 2010 insert—

P2para.Text: This Part deals with the application of the Corporation Tax Acts to manufactured dividend relationships and payments representative of dividends.
For the purposes of the Corporation Tax Acts a company has a manufactured dividend relationship if conditions A to C are met.
Condition A is that under any arrangements—

P3para.Text: an amount is payable by or to the company, or
any other benefit is given by or to the company (including the release of the whole or part of any liability to pay an amount).

P2para.Text: Condition B is that the arrangements relate to the transfer of shares in a company.
Condition C is that the amount or value of the other benefit—

P3para.Text: is representative of a dividend on the shares, or
will fall to be treated as representative of such a dividend when it is paid or given.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2) the reference to an amount being payable, or other benefit being given, by the company includes a reference to an amount being payable, or other benefit being given, by another person on behalf of the company.
In this Part—

Para.Text: “manufactured dividend”, in relation to a manufactured dividend relationship, means an amount, or the value of a benefit, within subsection (2), and
“the real dividend” means the dividend mentioned in subsection (4)(a).

P1group.Title: Treatment of payer of manufactured dividend

P2para.Text: This section applies where a company has a manufactured dividend relationship under which a manufactured dividend is paid by or on behalf of the company.
No deduction in calculating income for corporation tax purposes is allowed in respect of the manufactured dividend (subject to subsections (3) to (7)).

Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to the company so far as the manufactured dividend is brought into account under Part 3 of CTA 2009 in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the company.
Subsection (5) applies if—

P3para.Text: the manufactured dividend relates to investment business which the company has,
the company received the real dividend in the accounting period, and
the real dividend is taxed by virtue of section 548(5) (recipients of distributions from REITs).

P2para.Text: The manufactured dividend is to be treated as expenses of management of the company’s investment business for the accounting period for the purposes of Chapter 2 of Part 16 of CTA 2009.
Subsection (7) applies if—

P3para.Text: the manufactured dividend is referable to basic life assurance and general annuity business which the company has,
the company received the real dividend in the accounting period, and
the real dividend is taxed by virtue of section 548(5) (recipients of distributions from REITs).

P2para.Text: So far as the manufactured dividend is referable as mentioned in subsection (6)(a), the manufactured dividend is to be treated for the purposes of section 76 of FA 2012 as a deemed BLAGAB management expense for the accounting period.
Nothing in subsection (3) affects the question whether (apart from that provision) a deduction in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the company is allowed.
The references in subsections (4) and (6) to the real dividend include references to a manufactured dividend which is treated as a real dividend by virtue of section 814D(2).
For the purposes of subsections (6) and (7), the manufactured dividend is treated as referable to basic life assurance and general
annuity business so far as the real dividend is received by the company and is so referable in accordance with Chapter 4 of Part 2 of FA 2012 (apportionment rules for I-E charge).

P1group.Title: Treatment of recipient of manufactured dividend

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) applies if a company has a manufactured dividend relationship under which a manufactured dividend is payable to it.

For the purposes of the charge to corporation tax on the income of the company, the Corporation Tax Acts apply to the company, and any company claiming title through or under the company, as if the manufactured dividend were a dividend on the shares.
Subsection (2) is subject to subsections (4) to (8).

Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to a company so far as the manufactured dividend is brought into account under Part 3 of CTA 2009 in calculating the profits of a trade carried on by the company.
Subsection (2) does not apply in relation to a company for the purposes of determining entitlement to double taxation relief in respect of any dividend.
Part 9A of CTA 2009 (company distributions), in its application in relation to a manufactured dividend as a result of subsection (2), has effect with the modification in subsection (7).
The modification is that—

P3para.Text: references in that Part to the payer are to be treated as references to the company that pays the real dividend, and
the definition of “the payer” in section 931T is to be treated as omitted.

P2para.Text: The company to which the manufactured dividend is payable is not entitled to a tax credit under section 1109 (tax credits for certain recipients of exempt qualifying distributions) in respect of the dividend.
For the purposes of subsection (5) “double taxation relief” means any relief given under or as a result of Part 2 of TIOPA 2010.

This section has effect regardless of section 358 of CTA 2009 (exclusion of credits on release of connected companies debts) or any other provision of Part 5 of that Act (loan relationships) which prevents a credit from being brought into account.

P1group.Title: Charge to tax: arrangements conferring benefit on participator

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: a close company is at any time a party to tax avoidance arrangements, and
as a result of those arrangements, a benefit is conferred (whether directly or indirectly) on an individual who is—

P4para.Text: a participator in the company, or
an associate of such a participator.

P2para.Text: But this section does not apply if, or to the extent that, the conferral of the benefit gives rise to—

P3para.Text: a charge to tax on the company under section 455, or
a charge to income tax on the participator or associate.

P2para.Text: There is due from the company, as if it were an amount of corporation tax chargeable on the company for the accounting period in which the benefit is conferred on the participator or associate, an amount equal to 25% of the value of the benefit conferred.

Tax due under this section in relation to a benefit conferred on a participator or associate is due and payable in accordance with section 59D of TMA 1970 on the day following the end of the period of 9 months from the end of the accounting period in which the benefit was conferred.
If a company (C) controls another company (D), a participator in C is to be treated for the purposes of this section as being also a participator in D.
For the purposes of this section, arrangements are “tax avoidance arrangements” if the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of the arrangements is—

P3para.Text: to avoid or reduce, or obtain a relief or increased relief from, a charge to tax on the company under section 455, or
to obtain a tax advantage for the participator or associate.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “arrangements” includes any arrangements, scheme or understanding of any kind, whether or not legally enforceable, involving a single transaction or two or more transactions, and
“tax advantage” has the meaning given in section 1139, reading references to tax in that section as references to income tax.

P1group.Title: Relief in case of return payment to company

P2para.Text: Subsection (2) applies if a benefit has been conferred which gave rise to a charge to tax on the company under section 464A.
Relief is to be given from that tax, or a proportionate part of it, if—

P3para.Text: a payment (“the return payment”) is made to the company in respect of the benefit, and
no consideration is given for the return payment.

P2para.Text: Relief under this section is to be given on a claim, which must be made within 4 years from the end of the financial year in which the return payment is made to the company.
Subsection (5) applies if the return payment is made on or after the day on which tax under section 464A becomes due and payable in relation to the benefit.

Relief in respect of the return payment may not be given under this section at any time before the end of the period of 9 months from the end of the accounting period in which the return payment was made.
Schedule 1A to TMA 1970 (claims and elections not included in return) applies to a claim for relief under this section unless—

P3para.Text: the claim is included (by amendment or otherwise) in the return for the period in which the benefit was conferred, and
the relief may be given at the time the claim is made.

P2para.Text: The amendment made by this paragraph has effect in relation to arrangements to which a close company becomes a party on or after 20 March 2013.
After Chapter 3A insert—

P1group.Title: Restriction on relief under sections 458 and 464B

P2para.Text: Subsection (4) applies where, within any period of 30 days—

P3para.Text: one or more repayments totalling £5,000 or more are made to a close company in respect of one or more chargeable payments made by the company to a person, and
one or more chargeable payments totalling £5,000 or more are made by the company to the person or an associate of the person.

P2para.Text: Subsection (4) also applies where—

P3para.Text: immediately before a repayment is made, £15,000 or more is owed to a close company in respect of one or more chargeable payments made by the company to a person,
at any time after the repayment is made, the close company makes a chargeable payment (“the new payment”) to the person or an associate of the person, and
the condition in subsection (3) is met.

P2para.Text: The condition is that, at the time of the repayment—

P3para.Text: any person intended that the new payment would be made, or
arrangements had been made for the new payment to be made.

P2para.Text: Where this section applies, relief is not to be given under section 458(2) or 464B(2) (or, if already given, is to be withdrawn) in respect of whichever is the lower of the following amounts—

P3para.Text: the amount repaid, and
the amount of—

P4para.Text: in a case within subsection (1), the chargeable payments mentioned in paragraph (b) of that subsection, and
in a case within subsection (2), the new payment.

P2para.Text: Subsection (4) does not apply in relation to a repayment which gives rise to a charge to income tax on the participator or associate by reference to whom the loan, advance or benefit was a chargeable payment.
The Treasury may by order vary a sum specified in subsection (1) or (2).
An order under subsection (6) may contain incidental, supplemental, consequential and transitional provision and savings.
All such assessments and adjustments of assessments are to be made as are necessary to give effect to section 464C(4).

If a person who has made a tax return becomes aware that, after making it, anything in it has become incorrect because of the operation of section 464C(4), the person must give notice to an officer of Revenue and Customs specifying how the return needs to be amended.
The notice must be given within 3 months beginning with the day on which the person became aware that anything in the return had become incorrect because of the operation of section 464C(4).
In section 464C, “chargeable payment” means—

P3para.Text: a loan or advance made by a close company which gives rise to a charge to tax under section 455, or
the conferral of a benefit on an individual in circumstances which give rise to a charge to tax under section 464A.

P2para.Text: In a case within subsection (4)(b)—

P3para.Text: the conferral of the benefit is to be treated for the purposes of section 464C as a loan made by the close company to the individual to the value of the benefit conferred, and
any payment in respect of which (apart from section 464C) relief is due to the close company under section 464B is to be treated for the purposes of section 464C as a repayment of the loan.

P2para.Text: The amendment made by this paragraph has effect in relation to repayments and return payments made on or after 20 March 2013.

P1group.Title: Calculation of profits chargeable to corporation tax and supplementary charge

P1para.Text: In Chapter 4 of Part 8 of CTA 2010 (oil activities: calculation of profits), after section 298 insert—

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: a company that is or has been carrying on a ring fence trade (“the defaulter”) has defaulted on a liability under—

P4para.Text: a relevant agreement, or
an abandonment programme,

P3para.Text: to make a payment towards decommissioning expenditure,

another company that is or has been carrying on a ring fence trade (“the contributing company”) pays an amount (“the relevant contribution”) in or towards meeting the whole or part of the default, and
the amount of the relevant contribution is less than the sum of the amounts within subsection (2).

P2para.Text: The amounts within this subsection are—

P3para.Text: any payments made (directly or indirectly) to the contributing company by the guarantor under an abandonment guarantee as a result of the defaulter defaulting on the liability,
any reimbursement payments, and
any relief from tax which the contributing company obtains in respect of the relevant contribution.

P2para.Text: The difference between—

P3para.Text: the sum of the amounts within subsection (2), and
the relevant contribution,

P2para.Text: (“the relevant difference”) is to be treated as a receipt (in the nature of income) of the contributing company’s ring fence trade for the relevant accounting period (see subsection (4)).

“The relevant accounting period” means the accounting period that includes the day on which the Secretary of State certifies that the relevant abandonment programme has been satisfactorily completed (“the certification date”).
This is subject to subsections (5) and (6).
This is subject to subsections (5) and (6).
If the contributing company has ceased to carry on the ring fence trade before the certification date, “the relevant accounting period” is the last accounting period of the trade.

If the contributing company has ceased to be within the charge to corporation tax in respect of the ring fence trade before the certification date, “the relevant accounting period” is the accounting period during or at the end of which the contributing company ceased to be within the charge to corporation tax in respect of the trade.
The relevant difference is to be determined—

P3para.Text: in a case where subsection (5) or (6) applies, at the end of the calendar year in which the certification date falls, and
in any other case, at the end of the relevant accounting period.

P2para.Text: In a case where subsection (5) or (6) applies, any corporation tax chargeable for the relevant accounting period by virtue of this section is due and payable as if it were corporation tax for an accounting period beginning with the certification date.

Any additional assessment to corporation tax required in order to take account of a receipt arising under this section may be made at any time not later than 4 years after the end of the calendar year in which the certification date falls.
In this section—

Para.Text: “abandonment programme” means an abandonment programme approved under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998 (including such a programme as revised),
“decommissioning expenditure” has the meaning given by section 330C,

“reimbursement payment” means any payment made to the contributing company by the defaulter in reimbursing the contributing company in respect of, or otherwise making good to the contributing company, the whole or any part of the relevant contribution,
“the relevant abandonment programme” means the abandonment programme in respect of which the decommissioning expenditure mentioned in subsection (1)(a) was incurred, and
“relevant agreement” has the meaning given by section 104(5)(a) of FA 1991.

P1group.Title: Calculation of profits chargeable to income tax

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

an abandonment programme,

another person that is or has been carrying on a ring fence trade (“the contributing person”) pays an amount (“the relevant contribution”) in or towards meeting the whole or part of the default, and

P2para.Text: The amounts within this subsection are—

any reimbursement payments, and

P2para.Text: The difference between—

the relevant contribution,

P2para.Text: (“the relevant difference”) is to be treated as a receipt (in the nature of income) of the contributing person’s ring fence trade for the relevant tax year (see subsection (4)).

“The relevant tax year” means the tax year that includes the day on which the Secretary of State certifies that the relevant abandonment programme has been satisfactorily completed (“the certification date”).
This is subject to subsection (5).
This is subject to subsection (5).
If the contributing person’s ring fence trade is permanently discontinued before the certification date, “the relevant tax year” is the last tax year in which that trade is carried on.
The relevant difference is to be determined—

P3para.Text: in a case where subsection (5) applies, at the end of the tax year in which the certification date falls, and

P2para.Text: In a case where subsection (5) applies, any income tax chargeable for the relevant tax year by virtue of this section is due and payable for the tax year in which the certification date falls.

Any additional assessment to income tax required in order to take account of a receipt arising under this section may be made at any time not later than 4 years after the end of the tax year in which the certification date falls.
In this section—

Para.Text: “abandonment programme” means an abandonment programme approved under Part 4 of the Petroleum Act 1998 (including such a programme as revised),

“reimbursement payment” means any payment made to the contributing person by the defaulter in reimbursing the contributing person in respect of, or otherwise making good to the contributing person, the whole or any part of the relevant contribution,

After section 165 insert—

P1group.Title: Decommissioning services supplied by connected person

P2para.Text: Allowances under this Part are restricted under section 165B(1) if—

P3para.Text: a person (“R”) who is carrying on, or has ceased to carry on, a ring fence trade enters into an arrangement,
under the arrangement, a person (“S”) who is connected with R provides a service to R, and
all or part of the consideration for the service is decommissioning expenditure.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1)(b) may be satisfied whether the service is provided to R directly or indirectly; and in particular it does not matter—

P3para.Text: whether R and S are parties to the same contract, or
whether payments are made by R directly to S.

P2para.Text: Subsections (4) to (9) apply for the purposes of this section and sections 165B to 165E.
References to providing a service include—

P3para.Text: letting a ship on charter or any other asset on hire, and
providing goods which are to be used up in the course of providing a service.

P2para.Text: “Decommissioning expenditure” means expenditure in connection with decommissioning.
“Decommissioning” means—

P3para.Text: demolishing plant or machinery,
preserving plant or machinery pending its reuse or demolition,
preparing plant or machinery for reuse, or
arranging for the reuse of plant or machinery.

P2para.Text: It is immaterial for the purposes of subsection (6)(b) whether the plant or machinery is reused, is demolished or is partly reused and partly demolished.
It is immaterial for the purposes of subsection (6)(c) and (d) whether the plant or machinery is in fact reused.
References to R’s expenditure under the arrangement are to so much of the consideration for the service as is decommissioning expenditure incurred by R.
The amount, if any, by which R’s expenditure under the arrangement exceeds D is to be left out of account in determining R’s available qualifying expenditure.
D is the cost to S of providing the service or, if R’s expenditure under the arrangement relates to only part of the service, that part.
Subsection (2) is subject to sections 165C and 165D, which provide for D to be calculated differently in certain circumstances.

But if, under any arrangement, a particular service or part of a service is provided by more than one person who is connected with R (so that without this subsection there would be more than one amount for D in relation to that service or part), D is the lowest of those amounts.

P1group.Title: Allowance in respect of certain services related to decommissioning

P2para.Text: This section applies to so much of R’s expenditure under the arrangement as relates to the supply by S of a service if—

P3para.Text: the service is a planning or project management service, and
the cost plus method is an appropriate method of applying the arm’s length principle to the provision of it.

P2para.Text: D is the sum of—

P3para.Text: the cost to S of providing the service or, if R’s expenditure under the arrangement relates to only part of the service, that part, and
the appropriate percentage of that amount.

P2para.Text: The appropriate percentage is the smaller of—

P3para.Text: the appropriate mark up determined in accordance with the cost plus method, and

P2para.Text: Any expression which is used in this section and in the transfer pricing guidelines has the meaning given in those guidelines.
“The transfer pricing guidelines” has the meaning given by section 164(4) of TIOPA 2010.
“The transfer pricing guidelines” has the meaning given by section 164(4) of TIOPA 2010.

P1group.Title: Allowance where decommissioning undertaken for other participators in oil field

P2para.Text: This section applies where—

P3para.Text: S decommissions the plant or machinery,
there are, in addition to R, one or more other participators in the relevant field, and

the expenditure incurred in respect of the decommissioning is apportioned between the participators (including R) in accordance with their shares in the oil won from the relevant field or their shares in the equity of that field.

P2para.Text: D is the part of the expenditure referred to in subsection (1)(c) which is incurred by R.
Where—

P3para.Text: plant or machinery is or has been used in connection with the winning of oil from more than one relevant field, and

the expenditure incurred in respect of the decommissioning is apportioned between those fields in accordance with the contribution from each field to the total of the oil won using that plant or machinery,

P2para.Text: subsections (1) and (2) apply to each such field as if subsection (1)(c) referred to the expenditure apportioned to that field.
But subsections (2) and (3) do not apply (and section 165B(2) applies instead) if—

P3para.Text: the amount of consideration, or the method of determining the amount of consideration, to be received by S under the arrangement or arrangements, or
the apportionment of the liability for that consideration (whether between the participators as mentioned in subsection (1)(c) or between the fields as mentioned in subsection (3)(b)),

P2para.Text: has been agreed as, or as part of, an avoidance scheme.

A scheme is an “avoidance scheme” if the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of a party in entering into the scheme is to enable a person to obtain a tax advantage under this Part that would not otherwise be obtained.

The reference in subsection (5) to obtaining a tax advantage that would not otherwise be obtained includes obtaining an allowance that is in any way more favourable to a person than the one that would otherwise be obtained.
In this section—

Para.Text: “licensee”, “oil” and “oil field” have the same meaning as in Part 1 of OTA 1975,
“other participator” means a person, not connected with R, who is a licensee in respect of any licensed area wholly or partly included in the oil field in question, and
“relevant field” means an oil field—
in which plant or machinery is located, or
in connection with which the plant or machinery is being or has been used for the purposes of a ring fence trade.

P2para.Text: Allowances under this Part are restricted under subsection (5) if—

P3para.Text: a person (“R”) who is carrying on, or has ceased to carry on, a ring fence trade enters into a transaction with another person (“S”),
S receives from R consideration for services provided in pursuance of the transaction,
all or part of that consideration is decommissioning expenditure, and
the transaction either has an avoidance purpose, or is part of, or occurs as a result of, a scheme or arrangement that has an avoidance purpose.

P2para.Text: Subsection (1)(d) may be satisfied—

P3para.Text: whether the scheme or arrangement was made before or after the transaction was entered into, and
whether or not the scheme or arrangement is legally enforceable.

P2para.Text: A transaction, scheme or arrangement has an “avoidance purpose” if the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of a party in—

P3para.Text: entering into the transaction, scheme or arrangement, or
agreeing an amount of consideration, or a method of determining an amount of consideration, to be paid in pursuance of the transaction, scheme or arrangement,

P2para.Text: is to enable a person to obtain a tax advantage under this Part that would not otherwise be obtained.

The reference in subsection (3) to obtaining a tax advantage that would not otherwise be obtained includes obtaining an allowance that is in any way more favourable to a person than the one that would otherwise be obtained.
All or part of R’s expenditure under the transaction is to be left out of account in determining R’s available qualifying expenditure.
The amount of expenditure to be left out of account is—

P3para.Text: such amount as would or would in effect cancel out the tax advantage mentioned in subsection (3) (whether that advantage is obtained by R or another person and whether it relates to the transaction or something else), or
if the amount found under paragraph (a) exceeds the whole of R’s expenditure under the transaction, the whole of that expenditure.

P1group.Title: Site restoration services supplied by connected person

P2para.Text: Where—

P3para.Text: a person (“R”) who is carrying on, or has ceased to carry on, a ring fence trade enters into an arrangement,
under the arrangement, a person (“S”) who is connected with R provides a service to R in connection with work on the restoration of a relevant site, and
(in the absence of this section) all or part of the consideration for the service would be qualifying expenditure of R under section 416ZA,

P2para.Text: the amount of the expenditure which is qualifying expenditure is restricted under section 416ZD(1).
Subsection (1)(b) may be satisfied whether the service is provided to R directly or indirectly; and in particular it does not matter—

P3para.Text: whether R and S are parties to the same contract, or
whether payments are made by R directly to S.

P2para.Text: Subsections (4) and (5) apply for the purposes of this section and sections 416ZD and 416ZE.
“Relevant site” has the meaning given by section 416ZA(8).
References to providing a service include—

P3para.Text: letting a ship on charter or any other asset on hire, and
providing goods which are to be used up in the course of providing a service.

P2para.Text: In determining how much of the consideration for the service is qualifying expenditure, there is to be left out of account the amount (if any) by which that consideration exceeds D.
D is the cost to S of providing the service or, if the qualifying expenditure relates to only part of the service, that part.
Subsection (2) is subject to—

P3para.Text: subsection (4), and
section 416ZE,

P2para.Text: which provide for D to be calculated differently in certain circumstances.
The following provisions apply in relation to an amount restricted under subsection (1) as they apply in relation to an amount restricted under section 165B(1)—

P3para.Text: section 165C;
section 165E, subject to the modifications in subsection (5).

P2para.Text: The modifications are that—

P3para.Text: the references to Part 2 are to be read as references to this Part,
in subsection (1)(c), the reference to decommissioning expenditure is to be read as a reference to qualifying expenditure under section 416ZA, and
in subsection (5), the reference to R’s available qualifying expenditure is to be read as a reference to R’s qualifying expenditure on the restoration of the site.

P2para.Text: But if, under the arrangement, a particular service or part of a service is provided by more than one person who is connected with R (so that without this subsection there would be more than one amount for D in relation to that service or part), D is the lowest of those amounts.

P1group.Title: Allowance where site restoration undertaken for other participators in oil field

P2para.Text: This section applies where—

P3para.Text: S carries out the restoration of a relevant site,
there are, in addition to R, one or more other participators in the relevant field, and

the expenditure incurred in carrying out the restoration is apportioned between the participators (including R) in accordance with their shares in the oil won from the relevant field or their shares in the equity of that field.

P2para.Text: D is the part of the expenditure referred to in subsection (1)(c) which is incurred by R.
Where—

P3para.Text: a relevant site has been used in connection with the winning of oil from more than one relevant field, and
the expenditure incurred in respect of the restoration is apportioned between those fields in accordance with the contribution from each field to the total of the oil won using that site,

P2para.Text: subsections (1) and (2) apply to each such field as if subsection (1)(c) referred to the expenditure apportioned to that field.
But subsections (2) and (3) do not apply (and section 416ZD(2)applies instead) if—

P3para.Text: the amount of consideration, or the method of determining the amount of consideration, to be received by S under the arrangement or arrangements, or
the apportionment of the liability for that consideration (whether between the participators as mentioned in subsection (1)(c) or between the fields as mentioned in subsection (3)(b)),

P2para.Text: has been agreed as, or as part of, an avoidance scheme.

A scheme is an “avoidance scheme” if the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of a party in entering into the scheme is to enable a person to obtain a tax advantage under this Part that would not otherwise be obtained.

The reference in subsection (5) to obtaining a tax advantage that would not otherwise be obtained includes obtaining an allowance that is in any way more favourable to a person than the one that would otherwise be obtained.
In relation to the restoration of a relevant site, “relevant field” means any of the following—

P3para.Text: the oil field in which the site is located;
if the site is the site of a source to the working of which a ring fence trade relates (or related), an oil field from which oil is or has been won by means of working the source;
if the site is land used in connection with working such a source, an oil field from which oil is or has been won by means of working the source.

P2para.Text: In this section—

Para.Text: “licensee”, “oil” and “oil field” have the same meaning as in Part 1 of OTA 1975, and

TitleBlock.Title: Annual tax on enveloped dwellings: returns, enquiries, assessments and appeals

P2para.Text: The Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs may by regulations make provision about—

P3para.Text: the form and content of a return;
the method of delivering a return.

P2para.Text: Regulations under sub-paragraph (1) may make different provision for different purposes.
Every return must include a declaration by the person making it to the effect that the return is correct and complete to the best of the person’s knowledge.
A return is treated as containing any information provided by the person making the return for the purpose of completing the return.

P1para.Text: References in this Part of this Act to the delivery of an annual tax on enveloped dwellings return are to the delivery of a return that complies with all requirements imposed by or under any of sections 157, 158 and 158 and paragraph 1.

P1group.Title: Amendment of return by chargeable person

P2para.Text: A person who has delivered a return may amend the return by notice to an officer of Revenue and Customs.
The Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs may require that notices under this paragraph—

P3para.Text: are in a specified form, or
contain specified information.

P2para.Text: An amendment under this paragraph must be made by the end of the next chargeable period after the chargeable period to which the return relates (but see the exception that follows).

If a return is delivered on or after 1 January in the chargeable period next after that to which it relates, the latest time for amending the return under this paragraph is the end of the period of 3 months after the day on which the return is delivered.
An officer of Revenue and Customs may correct any obvious error or omission in a return.
A correction under this paragraph—

P3para.Text: is made by notice to the chargeable person, and
is regarded as effecting an amendment of the return.

P2para.Text: The reference in sub-paragraph (1) to an error includes, for instance, an arithmetical mistake or an error of principle.
A correction under this paragraph must be made within the 9 months beginning with—

P3para.Text: the day on which the return was delivered, or
if the correction is needed as a result of an amendment under paragraph 3, the day on which the amendment was made.

P2para.Text: A correction under this paragraph has no effect if the chargeable person—

P3para.Text: amends the return so as to reject the correction, or
gives a notice rejecting the correction in the special period mentioned in sub-paragraph (6).

P2para.Text: A notice is given in the “special period” if it is given—

P3para.Text: after the end of the period within which the chargeable person may amend the return, but
before the end of the 3 months beginning with the date of issue of the notice of correction.

P2para.Text: A notice under sub-paragraph (5)(b) must be given to HMRC.

Part.Title: Duty to keep and preserve records

P1group.Title: Duty to keep and preserve records

P2para.Text: A person who is required to deliver a return for a chargeable period must—

P3para.Text: keep any records that may be needed to enable the person to deliver a correct and complete return, and
preserve those records in accordance with this paragraph.

P2para.Text: The records must be preserved until the end of the later of the relevant day and the date on which—

P3para.Text: an enquiry into the return is completed, or
if there is no enquiry, an officer of Revenue and Customs no longer has power to enquire into the return.

P2para.Text: “The relevant day” means—

P3para.Text: the sixth anniversary of the last day of the chargeable period, or
any earlier day that may be specified in writing by the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs.

P2para.Text: Different days may be specified for different purposes under sub-paragraph (3)(b).
The records required to be kept and preserved under this paragraph include—

P3para.Text: details of any relevant transaction (including any contract or conveyance and any supporting maps, plans or similar documents and records of relevant payments, receipts and financial arrangements);
records of any valuation of the single-dwelling interest relevant to its value on any day in the chargeable period.

P2para.Text: The Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs may by regulations—

P3para.Text: provide that the records required to be kept under this paragraph do, or do not, include records specified in the regulations;
specify supporting documents that are required to be kept under this paragraph.

P2para.Text: Regulations under this paragraph may make provision by reference to things specified in a notice published by the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs in accordance with the regulations (and not withdrawn by a subsequent notice).
“Supporting documents” includes accounts, books, deeds, contracts, vouchers and receipts.

P1para.Text: The duty under paragraph 5 to preserve records may be satisfied—

P3para.Text: by preserving them in any form and by any means, or
by preserving the information contained in them in any form and by any means, subject to any conditions or exceptions specified in writing by the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs.

P1group.Title: Penalty for failure to keep and preserve records

P2para.Text: A person who fails to comply with paragraph 5 in relation to a chargeable period is liable to a penalty not exceeding £3,000, subject to the following exception.

No penalty is incurred if an officer of Revenue and Customs is satisfied that any facts that it is reasonable to require should be proved to HMRC, and that would have been proved by the records, are proved by other documentary evidence provided to them.
An officer of Revenue and Customs may enquire into a return if sub-paragraph (2) has been complied with.
Notice of the intention to make an enquiry must be given—

P3para.Text: to the person by whom or on whose behalf the return was delivered (“the relevant person”);
before the end of the period of 12 months after the relevant date.

P2para.Text: The relevant date is—

P3para.Text: the filing date, if the return was delivered on or before that date;
the date on which the return was delivered, if the return was delivered after the filing date;
the date on which the amendment was made, if the return is amended under paragraph 3 (amendment by person making the return).

P2para.Text: A return that has been the subject of one notice under this paragraph may not be the subject of another, except a notice given in consequence of an amendment (or another amendment) of the return under paragraph 3.
A notice under this paragraph is referred to as a “notice of enquiry”.
An enquiry extends to anything contained in the return, or required to be contained in the return, that relates—

P3para.Text: to the question whether the relevant person is chargeable to tax with respect to the interest to which the return relates for the chargeable period concerned, or
to the amount of tax chargeable on the relevant person with respect to that interest for that period.

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (3) applies if the notice of enquiry is given as a result of the amendment of a return under paragraph 3 (amendment by person making the return)—

P3para.Text: at a time when it is no longer possible to give a notice of enquiry under paragraph 8(3)(a) or (b), or
after an enquiry into the return has been completed.

P2para.Text: The enquiry is limited to—

P3para.Text: matters to which the amendment relates, and
matters affected by the amendment.

P1group.Title: Amendment of self assessment during enquiry to prevent loss of tax

P2para.Text: If at a time when an enquiry is in progress into a return an officer of Revenue and Customs forms the opinion—

P3para.Text: that the amount stated in the self assessment contained in the return as the amount of tax payable is insufficient, and
that unless the assessment is immediately amended there is likely to be a loss of tax to the Crown,

P2para.Text: the officer may by notice in writing to the relevant person amend the assessment to make good the deficiency.

If the enquiry is one that is limited by paragraph 9(2) and (3) to matters arising from an amendment of the return, sub-paragraph (1) above applies only so far as the deficiency is attributable to the amendment.
For the purposes of this paragraph the period during which an enquiry is in progress is the whole of the period—

P3para.Text: beginning with the day on which the notice of enquiry is given, and
ending with the day on which the enquiry is completed.

P1group.Title: Referral of questions to tribunal during enquiry

P2para.Text: At any time when an enquiry is in progress into a return any question arising in connection with the subject-matter of the return may be referred to the tribunal for determination.
Notice of the referral must be given to the tribunal jointly by the relevant person and an officer of Revenue and Customs.
More than one notice of referral may be given under this paragraph in relation to an enquiry.
For the purposes of this paragraph the period during which an enquiry is in progress is the whole of the period—

P3para.Text: beginning with the day on which the notice of enquiry is given, and
ending with the day on which the enquiry is completed.

P1para.Text: An officer of Revenue and Customs or the relevant person may withdraw a notice of referral under paragraph 11.

P2para.Text: While proceedings on a referral under paragraph 11 are in progress in relation to an enquiry—

P3para.Text: no closure notice may be given in relation to the enquiry, and
no application may be made for a direction to give a closure notice.

P2para.Text: Proceedings on a referral are “in progress” where—

P3para.Text: notice of referral has been given and has not been withdrawn, and
the questions referred have not been finally determined.

P2para.Text: A question referred has been “finally determined” when—

P3para.Text: it has been determined by the tribunal, and
there is no further possibility of the determination being varied or set aside (disregarding any power to grant permission to appeal out of time).

P2para.Text: A determination under paragraph 11 is binding on the parties to the referral in the same way, and to the same extent, as a decision on a preliminary issue in an appeal.
The officer of Revenue and Customs conducting the enquiry must take the determination into account—

P3para.Text: in reaching conclusions on the enquiry, and
in the formulation of any amendments of the return that may be required to give effect to those conclusions.

P2para.Text: The question determined may not be reopened on an appeal, except to the extent that it could be reopened if it had been determined as a preliminary issue in that appeal.

P1group.Title: Tribunal to which referrals are made

P2para.Text: Where the question to be referred under paragraph 11 is of the market value of any single-dwelling interest, the referral is to be made to—

P3para.Text: the Upper Tribunal, if the land is in England and Wales;
the Lands Tribunal for Scotland, if the land is in Scotland;
the Lands Tribunal for Northern Ireland, if the land is in Northern Ireland.

P2para.Text: In any other case a referral under paragraph 11 is to be made to—

P3para.Text: the First-tier Tribunal, or
where determined by or under Tribunal Procedure Rules, the Upper Tribunal.

P2para.Text: References to “the tribunal” in paragraphs 11 and 13 are to be read accordingly.

An enquiry under paragraph 8 is completed when an officer of Revenue and Customs informs the relevant person by a notice (a “closure notice”) that the enquiry is complete and states the conclusions reached in the enquiry.
A closure notice must either—

P3para.Text: state that in the officer’s opinion no amendment of the return is required, or
make the amendments of the return required to give effect to the officer’s conclusions.

P2para.Text: A closure notice takes effect when it is issued.
The relevant person may apply to the tribunal for a direction that a closure notice is to be given within a specified period.
The tribunal hearing the application must give a direction unless satisfied that HMRC have reasonable grounds for not giving a closure notice within that period.
In this paragraph “the tribunal” means—

P3para.Text: the First-tier Tribunal, or
where determined by or under Tribunal Procedure Rules, the Upper Tribunal.

Part.Title: HMRC determination where no return delivered

P1group.Title: Determination of tax chargeable if no return delivered

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where condition A or condition B is met.
Condition A is that—

P3para.Text: an officer of Revenue and Customs has reason to believe that a person (“P”) is chargeable to tax for a chargeable period in respect of a single-dwelling interest,
P has not made an annual tax on enveloped dwellings return for the period in respect of the interest, and
the relevant filing date has passed.

P2para.Text: Condition B is that—

P3para.Text: an officer of Revenue and Customs has reason to believe that additional tax is payable by a person (“P”) under section 161(3) for a chargeable period in respect of a single-dwelling interest,
P has not made an annual tax on enveloped dwellings return for the period in respect of the interest, and
the relevant filing date has passed.

P2para.Text: “The relevant filing date” means the date by which the officer believes a return was required to be delivered.

The officer may make a determination (an “HMRC determination”) to the best of the officer’s information and belief of the amount of tax to which P is chargeable for the period concerned with respect to the interest.
Notice of the determination must be given to P and must state the date on which it is issued.
No HMRC determination may be made more than 4 years after the end of the chargeable period to which it relates.

P1group.Title: Determination to have effect as a self assessment

P2para.Text: A determination under paragraph 18 has effect for enforcement purposes as if it were a self assessment made by P.
In sub-paragraph (1) “for enforcement purposes” means for the purposes of section 163 and Schedule 12 to FA 2003 (collection and recovery of tax etc).
Nothing in this paragraph affects any liability of a person to a penalty for failure to deliver a return.

P1group.Title: Determination superseded by actual self assessment

P2para.Text: If after an HMRC determination has been made P delivers a return for the chargeable period with respect to the interest in question, the self assessment included in that return supersedes the determination.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not apply to a return delivered—

P3para.Text: more than 4 years after the power to make the determination first became exercisable, or
more than 12 months after the date of the determination,

P2para.Text: whichever is the later.
Where—

P3para.Text: proceedings have been begun for the recovery of any tax charged by an HMRC determination, and
before the proceedings are concluded the determination is superseded by a self assessment,

P2para.Text: the proceedings may be continued as if they were proceedings for the recovery of so much of the tax charged by the self assessment as is due and payable and has not yet been paid.

P1group.Title: Assessment where loss of tax discovered

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (2) applies if an officer of Revenue and Customs discovers that—

P3para.Text: an amount of tax that ought to have been assessed under this Part of this Act as tax chargeable on a person for a chargeable period with respect to a single-dwelling interest has not been assessed,
an assessment of the tax chargeable on a person for a chargeable period in respect of a single-dwelling interest is or has become insufficient, or
relief has been given that is or has become excessive.

P2para.Text: An officer of Revenue and Customs may make an assessment (a “discovery assessment”) in the amount or further amount that ought in the officer’s opinion to be charged in order to make good to the Crown the loss of tax.
The functions of an officer of Revenue and Customs under this paragraph are also exercisable by the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs.

P1group.Title: Assessment to recover excessive repayment of tax

P2para.Text: If an amount of tax has been, but ought not to have been, repaid to a person that amount may be assessed and recovered as if it were unpaid tax.
If the repayment was made with interest, the amount assessed and recovered may include the amount of interest that ought not to have been paid.

P1para.Text: In paragraphs 24 to 27 references to “the taxpayer” are to the person mentioned in paragraph 21(1)(a) or (b) or 22(1).

P1group.Title: Conditions for making assessment where return has been delivered

P2para.Text: If the taxpayer has delivered a return in respect of the interest in question for the chargeable period in question, an assessment under paragraph 21 or 22may only be made in the two cases specified in sub-paragraphs (2) and (3).
The first case is where the situation mentioned in paragraph 21(1) or 22(1) was brought about carelessly or deliberately by—

P3para.Text: the taxpayer,
a person acting on behalf of the taxpayer, or
a person who was a partner of the taxpayer at the relevant time.

P2para.Text: The second case is where it could not reasonably have been expected that an officer of Revenue and Customs in possession of the information made available to HMRC before the relevant time would be aware at the relevant time of the situation mentioned in paragraph 21(1) or 22(1).
In sub-paragraph (3) “the relevant time” means the time HMRC—

P3para.Text: ceased to be entitled to give a notice of enquiry into the return, or
completed their enquiries into the return.

P2para.Text: For this purpose information is regarded as made available to HMRC if—

P3para.Text: it is contained in a return delivered by the taxpayer,
it is contained in any documents produced or information provided to an officer of Revenue and Customs for the purposes of an enquiry into any such return,

it is information the existence and relevance of which officers of Revenue and Customs could reasonably have been expected to infer from information made available as mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b), or
it is information the existence and relevance of which was notified to an officer of Revenue and Customs by the taxpayer or a person acting on the taxpayer’s behalf.
