If for any relevant period accounts for a person are not prepared in accordance with international accounting standards or UK generally accepted accounting practice, any question relating to generally accepted accounting practice is to be determined for the purposes of this section in relation to that person for that period by reference to generally accepted accounting practice in relation to accounts prepared in accordance with international accounting standards.
In this section “accounts”, in relation to a company, includes accounts relating to two or more companies of which that company is one.

P1group.Title: Limit on double taxation relief in cases involving qualifying loan relationships of CFCs

P1para.Text: Part 2 of TIOPA 2010 (double taxation relief) is amended as follows.
Chapter 2 (double taxation relief by way of credit) is amended as follows.
In section 42 (limit on credit against corporation tax) after subsection (4) insert—

P2para.Text: See also section 49A which contains an additional limit on credit allowed in certain cases involving CFCs.

P1para.Text: After section 49 insert—

P1group.Title: Limit on credit in cases involving qualifying loan relationships of CFCs

P2para.Text: This section applies if—

P3para.Text: a claim is made under Chapter 9 of Part 9A (controlled foreign companies: exemptions for profits from qualifying loan relationships) in relation to an accounting period (“the relevant period”) of a CFC (“the creditor CFC”),
in the relevant period, the creditor CFC has a qualifying loan relationship in relation to which another CFC is the ultimate debtor by virtue of section 371IG(4) or (5), and
a UK resident company (“the relevant UK company”) has loan relationship credits which arise in the relevant period from—

P4para.Text: loan B (see section 371IG(3)(b)), or
loans out of which loan B is wholly or partly funded (directly or indirectly).

P2para.Text: So far as any credit allowed under section 18(2) to the relevant UK company is referable to loan relationship credits falling within subsection (1)(c) which arise in an accounting period of the relevant UK company, the credit must not exceed—

Para.Text: where—
R has the same meaning as in section 42(2), and
S is—
the relevant UK company’s share of the relevant profit amount (see subsection (4)), or
if only X% of the total amount of the loan relationship credits falling within subsection (1)(c) arises in the accounting period, X% of the relevant UK company’s share of the relevant profit amount.

P2para.Text: (If the amount given by the formula above is nil, no credit is allowed.)
The limit on credit contained in subsection (2) is in addition to the limit given by section 42(2).
Take the following steps to determine the relevant profit amount and the relevant UK company’s share of that amount.
Determine the total amount of the loan relationship credits which arise in the relevant period from loan B to the person who made loan B.
Deduct from the amount determined at step 1 above the credits from the creditor CFC’s qualifying loan relationship determined at step 1 in section 371IF for the relevant period.
The result is the relevant profit amount.
On a just and reasonable basis, apportion the relevant profit amount amongst all the persons falling within subsection (5) (although the amount apportioned to a person may be nil).
The relevant UK company’s share of the relevant profit amount is the amount apportioned to it (and is nil if no amount is apportioned to it).
The following persons (apart from the creditor CFC) fall within this subsection—

P3para.Text: the person who made loan B, and
any person who has made or received a loan out of which loan B is wholly or partly funded (directly or indirectly).

P2para.Text: In this section—

P3para.Text: references to loan B do not include any part of loan B—

P4para.Text: which loan A (see section 371IG(3)(a)) is not made and used to fund, or
in relation to which the requirement of section 371IG(3)(c) is not met,

P3para.Text: “loan relationship credit” means, in relation to a person, a credit which the person has under Part 5 of CTA 2009 or would have were the person a UK resident company within the charge to corporation tax, and
“loan” has the same meaning as it has in Chapter 9 of Part 9A.

P2para.Text: In Chapter 3 (miscellaneous provisions), section 112 (deduction from income for foreign tax (instead of credit against UK tax)) is amended as follows.
After subsection (3) insert—
Subsection (3B) applies if—

P3para.Text: the requirements of section 49A(1)(a) to (c) are met,
amounts have been paid in respect of non-UK tax on loan relationship credits falling within section 49A(1)(c) which arise in an accounting period of the relevant UK company, and
apart from subsection (3B), Z would exceed R×S, where—

Para.Text: Z is—
the total amount of any reductions under subsection (1) for amounts paid in respect of that non-UK tax, less
the total amount of any increases under subsection (3) for payments made by reference to that non-UK tax, and
R and S have the same meaning as in section 49A(2).

P2para.Text: The total amount of the reductions under subsection (1) is to be reduced so that Z equals R×S.
In subsection (6), for “subsection (1)” substitute “this section”.

P1para.Text: In Part 6 of TIOPA 2010 (tax arbitrage), in section 236 (deduction schemes involving hybrid entities) for subsection (4) substitute—

P2para.Text: Condition B is not met just because the party’s profits or gains are subject to a charge under the law of a territory outside the United Kingdom (by whatever name known) which is similar to the CFC charge (see Part 9A).

P1para.Text: Part 9A of TIOPA 2010 (controlled foreign companies) is amended as follows.
In Chapter 3 (the CFC charge gateway: determining which (if any) of Chapters 4 to 8 applies) in section 371CE (does Chapter 6 apply?) for subsections (4) and (5) substitute—

P2para.Text: The CFC is a “group treasury company” in the accounting period if, assuming the relevant period were the accounting period—

P3para.Text: the CFC would be a group treasury company in the relevant period in accordance with section 316(2) (group treasury companies), and
throughout the relevant period, the requirements of section 316(3)(a) and (b) would be met in relation to the CFC as a group treasury company.

P2para.Text: For the purpose of applying section 316 in accordance with subsection (4)—

P3para.Text: section 316(2) applies with the omission of paragraph (d), and
section 337(1) (definition of “the worldwide group”) applies with the omission of paragraph (a).

P1para.Text: Chapter 9 (exemptions for profits from qualifying loan relationships) is amended as follows.
In section 371IB (loans funded out of qualifying resources) after subsection (9) insert—

P2para.Text: Subsection (9) does not apply if the debt incurred by the member of the CFC group as mentioned in subsection (8) represents the principal on a loan made to the member to which subsection (9B) or (9D) applies.
This subsection applies to a loan if the member repays it within 48 hours of the loan being made.

But subsection (9B) does not apply to a loan if the repayment of the loan within the 48 hours occurs under, or is connected (directly or indirectly) with, an arrangement the main purpose, or one of the main purposes, of which is to ensure that subsection (9) does not apply because of—

P3para.Text: the loan, or
any other debt which a member of the CFC group incurs (or is expected to incur) in the United Kingdom.

P2para.Text: This subsection applies to a loan if—

P3para.Text: there is an issue of shares which meets the requirements of subsection (7)(c)(i) to (iii),
the loan was made before the issue of shares but with the expectation that it would be repaid by the member out of funds deriving (directly or indirectly) from the issue of shares,
the loan is repaid by the member out of such funds within the period of 6 months beginning with the day on which the loan was made, and
the loan—

P4para.Text: was made by a person who was not a member of the CFC group, and
was not made (wholly or partly nor directly or indirectly) out of funds or other assets provided by a member of the CFC group.

P1para.Text: The amendments made by this Schedule are treated as having come into force on 1 January 2013.

Text.Emphasis: Accounting periods ending on or after 20 March 2013

P2para.Text: The following sub-paragraphs apply for accounting periods ending on or after 20 March 2013.
A notice may be given under subsection (2)(b) even though the requirement of subsection (2)(a) is not met.

If a notice is given under subsection (2)(b) in a case where the requirement of subsection (2)(a) is not met, the CFC’s trading finance profits are to be apportioned on a just and reasonable basis between—

P3para.Text: the part of the accounting period falling before 20 March 2013 (“period A”), and
the remaining part of the accounting period (“period B”).

P2para.Text: So far as the CFC’s trading finance profits are apportioned to period A, they are to be treated as non-trading finance profits if the CFC is a group treasury company in period A (and subsection (3) applies to them accordingly).
For the purpose of determining if the CFC is a group treasury company in period A, subsection (4) applies—

P3para.Text: as if references to the accounting period were to period A, and
as if paragraph (b) were omitted.

P2para.Text: So far as the CFC’s trading finance profits are apportioned to period B, they are to be treated as non-trading finance profits if the CFC is a group treasury company in period B (and subsection (3) applies to them accordingly).
For the purpose of determining if the CFC is a group treasury company in period B, subsection (4) applies as if references to the accounting period were to period B.

TitleBlock.Title: Corporation tax: deferral of payment of exit charge

P1para.Text: TMA 1970 is amended in accordance with paragraphs 2 to 6.
After section 59F insert—

P2para.Text: Schedule 3ZB contains provisions about exit charge payment plans in accordance with which companies may defer payment of certain corporation tax.

Parts 1 and 2 of the Schedule each make provision about the circumstances in which an exit charge payment plan may be entered into, and about determining the amount of corporation tax that may be deferred—

P3para.Text: see Part 1 in relation to a company which ceases to be resident in the United Kingdom, and
see Part 2 in relation to a company which is not resident in the United Kingdom but which carries on, or has carried on, a trade in the United Kingdom through a permanent establishment there.

P2para.Text: Part 3 of the Schedule contains provision about—

P3para.Text: entering into an exit charge payment plan,
the effect of such a plan,
the content of such a plan, and
the methods in accordance with which tax deferred under such a plan may be paid.

P1para.Text: Immediately before section 59G insert—

P2para.Text: Section 109B (provision for securing payment by company of outstanding tax) is amended as follows.

In subsection (4)(b), at the end insert “(which may include a proposal to enter into an exit charge payment plan in accordance with Schedule 3ZB).”
After subsection (5) insert—
Condition D does not apply to the extent that payment of the tax is to be secured by the company entering into an exit charge payment plan in accordance with Schedule 3ZB.
Section 109E (liability of other persons for unpaid tax) is amended as follows.
After subsection (1) insert—
The reference in subsection (1)(b) to the time when tax becomes payable is a reference to—

P3para.Text: in a case where an exit charge payment plan has been entered into in accordance with Schedule 3ZB in respect of the tax, the time when the tax becomes payable under the plan, and
in any other case, the time when the tax becomes payable in accordance with section 59D or 59E.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2), for “the time when the amount of the tax is finally determined” substitute “the relevant time”.
After subsection (2) insert—
In subsection (2) the “relevant time” means—

P3para.Text: in a case where an exit charge payment plan has been entered into in accordance with Schedule 3ZB in respect of the tax, the later of—

P4para.Text: the first day after the period of 12 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period (as defined in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 3ZB, as the case may be), and
the date on which the tax is payable under the plan, and

P3para.Text: in any other case, the time when the amount of the tax is finally determined.

P1para.Text: After Schedule 3ZA insert—

TitleBlock.Title: Exit charge payment plans

Part.Title: company ceasing to be resident in UK

P1group.Title: Circumstances in which exit charge payment plan may be entered into

P2para.Text: This Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule apply where an eligible company—

P3para.Text: ceases to be resident in the United Kingdom,
on ceasing to be so resident, becomes resident in another EEA state, and
is liable to pay qualifying corporation tax in respect of the migration accounting period.

P2para.Text: The company may defer payment of some or all of the qualifying corporation tax if it enters into an exit charge payment plan in respect of it in accordance with this Schedule.
The company may enter into an exit charge payment plan only if conditions A to C are met.
Condition A is that before the end of the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period—

P3para.Text: an application to enter into the exit charge payment plan is made to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs, and
the application contains details of all the matters which are required by Part 3 of this Schedule to be specified in the plan.

P2para.Text: Condition B is that on ceasing to be resident in the United Kingdom, the company carries on a business in an EEA state.

Condition C is that, on becoming resident in the other EEA state, the company is not treated as resident in a territory outside the European Economic Area for the purposes of any double taxation arrangements.
In this paragraph—

Para.Text: “double taxation arrangements” means arrangements which are made by two or more territories with a view to affording relief from double taxation and which have effect at the time when the company ceases to be resident in the United Kingdom;

“eligible company” means a company that has a right to freedom of establishment protected by Article 49 of the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union or established by Article 31 of the Agreement on the European Economic Area.

P2para.Text: In this Part of this Schedule—

P3para.Text: references to the migration accounting period are to—

P4para.Text: in a case where an accounting period comes to an end on the company ceasing to be resident in the United Kingdom, that accounting period, and
in a case not falling within sub-paragraph (i), the accounting period during which the company ceases to be resident in the United Kingdom,

P3para.Text: references to a Part 1 company are to a company in relation to which this Part of this Schedule applies, and
references to Part 3 of this Schedule are to Part 3 of this Schedule as it applies to a Part 1 company.

P2para.Text: The company is liable to pay qualifying corporation tax in respect of the migration accounting period if CT1 is greater than CT2 where—

Para.Text: CT1 is the corporation tax which the company is liable to pay for the accounting period, and

CT2 is the corporation tax which the company would be liable to pay for the accounting period if any income, profits, gains, losses or debits arising only by virtue of the exit charge provisions were ignored,

P2para.Text: (CT2 will be zero if the company would not be liable to pay any corporation tax for the period).
The amount of qualifying corporation tax which the company is liable to pay is the difference between CT1 and CT2.
“Exit charge provisions” means—

P3para.Text: section 185 of the 1992 Act,
section 187(4) of that Act, where that subsection applies by virtue of section 187(4)(c),
section 162 of CTA 2009, where that section applies by virtue of section 41(2)(b) of that Act,
section 333 of that Act,
section 609 of that Act,
section 859 of that Act, where that section applies by virtue of section 859(2)(a), and
section 862 of that Act, where that section applies by virtue of section 862(1)(c).

P2para.Text: References in this Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule to qualifying corporation tax are to be read in accordance with this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Interpretation: exit charge assets and liabilities

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies for the purposes of this Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule.

“Exit charge assets” and “exit charge liabilities” means assets or liabilities (as the case may be) in respect of which income, profits or gains arise in the migration accounting period by virtue of the exit charge provisions, and in particular—

P3para.Text: “TCGA or trading stock exit charge assets” means those exit charge assets, other than pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed assets, in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 2(3)(a), (b) or (c),

“financial exit charge assets or liabilities” means those exit charge assets or liabilities in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 2(3)(d) or (e),
“intangible exit charge assets” means—

P4para.Text: those exit charge assets in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 2(3)(f) or (g), and
those exit charge assets which are pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed assets in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 2(3)(a) or (b).

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2)—

P3para.Text: “exit charge provisions” has the meaning given in paragraph 2(3);
“pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed asset” means an intangible fixed asset which is a pre-FA 2002 asset (as defined in section 881 of CTA 2009).

Part.Title: Non-UK resident companies with UK permanent establishments

P1group.Title: Circumstances in which exit charge payment plan may be entered into

P2para.Text: This Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule apply where—

P3para.Text: at any time during an accounting period (“the migration accounting period”) an eligible company which is not resident in the United Kingdom carries on a trade in the United Kingdom through a permanent establishment there,
one or more PE qualifying events occurs in respect of any assets or liabilities of the company as mentioned in sub-paragraph (4), and
the company is liable to pay qualifying corporation tax in respect of the migration accounting period.

P2para.Text: The company may defer payment of some or all of the qualifying corporation tax if it enters into an exit charge payment plan in respect of it in accordance with this Schedule.
The company may enter into an exit charge payment plan only if before the end of the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period—

P3para.Text: an application to enter into the exit charge payment plan is made to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs, and
the application contains details of all the matters which are required by Part 3 of this Schedule to be specified in the plan.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this Part of this Schedule, a “PE qualifying event” occurs in respect of an asset or liability of a company if—

P3para.Text: an event occurs which triggers—

P4para.Text: a deemed disposal and reacquisition of the asset or liability under the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(a), (c), (d) or (e), or
a valuation of the asset under the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(b),

P3para.Text: the event—

P4para.Text: occurs during the migration accounting period, or
causes the migration accounting period to come to an end, and

P3para.Text: at the time of the event, the company is not treated as resident in a territory outside the European Economic Area for the purposes of any double taxation arrangements.

P2para.Text: In this Part of this Schedule, references to a PE qualifying asset or liability are to an asset or liability in respect of which a PE qualifying event occurs.
In this paragraph “double taxation arrangements” and “eligible company” have the meanings given in paragraph 1(7).
In this Part of this Schedule—

P3para.Text: references to the migration accounting period are to be read in accordance with this paragraph;
references to a Part 2 company are to a company in relation to which this Part of this Schedule applies,
references to Part 3 of this Schedule are to Part 3 of this Schedule as it applies to a Part 2 company, and
“permanent establishment”, in relation to a company, is to be read in accordance with Chapter 2 of Part 24 of CTA 2010.

P2para.Text: The company is liable to pay qualifying corporation tax in respect of the migration accounting period if CT1 is greater than CT2 where—

Para.Text: CT1 is the corporation tax which the company is liable to pay for the accounting period, and

CT2 is the corporation tax which the company would be liable to pay for the accounting period if any income, profits, gains, losses or debits arising as a result of any PE qualifying events, and arising only by virtue of the exit charge provisions, were ignored,

P2para.Text: (CT2 will be zero if the company would not be liable to pay any corporation tax for the period).
The amount of qualifying corporation tax which the company is liable to pay is the difference between CT1 and CT2.
Exit charge provisions means—

P3para.Text: section 25 of the 1992 Act,
section 162 of CTA 2009, where that section applies by virtue of section 41(2)(b) of that Act,
section 334 of that Act,
section 610 of that Act, and
section 859 of that Act, where that section applies by virtue of section 859(2)(b).

P2para.Text: References in this Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule to qualifying corporation tax are to be read in accordance with this paragraph.

P1group.Title: Interpretation: exit charge assets and liabilities

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies for the purposes of this Part of this Schedule and Part 3 of this Schedule.

“Exit charge assets” and “exit charge liabilities” means any PE qualifying assets or liabilities (as the case may be) in respect of which income, profits or gains arise in the migration accounting period by virtue of the exit charge provisions, and in particular—

P3para.Text: “TCGA or trading stock exit charge assets” means those exit charge assets, other than pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed assets, in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(a) or (b);

“financial exit charge assets or liabilities” means those exit charge assets or liabilities in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(c) or (d);
“intangible exit charge assets” means—

P4para.Text: those exit charge assets in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(e), and
those exit charge assets which are pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed assets in respect of which income, profits or gains arise by virtue of the exit charge provision mentioned in paragraph 5(3)(a).

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2)—

P3para.Text: “exit charge provisions” has the meaning given in paragraph 5(3);
“pre-FA 2002 intangible fixed asset” means an intangible fixed asset which is a pre-FA 2002 asset (as defined in section 881 of CTA 2009).

Part.Title: Entering into an exit charge payment plan

P2para.Text: As to when this Part of this Schedule applies, see—

P3para.Text: Part 1 of this Schedule (companies ceasing to be resident in the United Kingdom), and
Part 2 of this Schedule (companies with permanent establishments in the United Kingdom).

P2para.Text: In this Part of this Schedule, as it applies to a company in relation to which Part 1 of this Schedule applies, terms and expressions which are used in this Part and in that Part have the same meanings in this Part as in that Part.

In this Part of this Schedule, as it applies to a company in relation to which Part 2 of this Schedule applies, terms and expressions which are used in this Part and in that Part have the same meanings in this Part as in that Part.

P1group.Title: Entering into an exit charge payment plan

P2para.Text: A Part 1 company or a Part 2 company enters into an exit charge payment plan in respect of qualifying corporation tax in accordance with this Schedule if—

P3para.Text: the company agrees to pay, and an officer of Revenue and Customs agrees to accept payment of, the tax in accordance with the standard instalment method (see paragraph 13) or the realisation method (see paragraphs 14 to 17) or a combination of the two methods,
the company agrees to pay interest on the tax in accordance with paragraph 9(3), and
the plan meets the requirements set out in paragraphs 10 to 12 as to the matters that must be specified in it.

P2para.Text: The exit charge payment plan may, in the circumstances mentioned in sub-paragraph (3), contain appropriate provision regarding security for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs in respect of the deferred payment of the tax.

Those circumstances are where an officer of Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs considers that agreeing to accept payment of qualifying corporation tax in accordance with the plan would present a serious risk as to collection of the tax in the absence of provision regarding security in respect of that tax.

An exit charge payment plan is void if any information furnished by the company in connection with the plan does not fully and accurately disclose all facts and considerations material to the decision of the officer of Revenue and Customs to accept payment of qualifying corporation tax in accordance with the plan.

P1group.Title: Effect of exit charge payment plan

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where an exit charge payment plan is entered into by a company in respect of qualifying corporation tax in accordance with this Schedule.
As regards when the tax is payable—

P3para.Text: the plan does not prevent the tax becoming due and payable under section 59D or 59E, but
the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs—

P4para.Text: may not seek payment of the tax otherwise than in accordance with the plan;
may make repayments in respect of any amount of the tax paid, or any amount paid on account of the tax, before the plan is entered into.

P2para.Text: As regards interest—

P3para.Text: the tax carries interest in accordance with Part 9 as if the plan had not been entered into, and
each time a payment is made under the plan, it is to be paid together with any interest payable on it.

P2para.Text: As regards penalties, the company will be liable to penalties for late payment of the tax only if it fails to make payments in accordance with the plan (see item 6ZA of the Table at the end of paragraph 1 of Schedule 56 to the Finance Act 2009).

Qualifying corporation tax payable in accordance with an exit charge payment plan which is for the time being unpaid may be paid at any time before it becomes payable under the plan together with interest payable on it to the date of payment.

P1group.Title: Content of exit charge payment plan

P2para.Text: An exit charge payment plan entered into by a Part 1 company must specify—

P3para.Text: the date on which the company ceased to be resident in the United Kingdom, and
the EEA state in which the company has become resident.

P2para.Text: An exit charge payment plan entered into by a Part 2 company must specify—

P3para.Text: the EEA state in which the company is resident, and
if the company has ceased to carry on a trade in the United Kingdom through a permanent establishment there, the date on which it ceased to do so.

P2para.Text: In either case an exit charge payment plan entered into by a company must also specify—

P3para.Text: the amount of qualifying corporation tax which, in the company’s opinion, is payable by it in respect of the migration accounting period,
the amount of that qualifying corporation tax which the company wishes to defer paying under the exit charge payment plan (“ECPP tax”), and
whether the ECPP tax is to be paid in accordance with—

P4para.Text: the standard instalment method (see paragraph 13),
the realisation method (see paragraphs 14 to 17), or
a combination of the two methods.

P2para.Text: If the ECPP tax is to be paid in accordance with a combination of the two methods, the exit charge payment plan must also specify—

P3para.Text: in the case of each of the company’s exit charge assets or liabilities (see paragraphs 3(2) or 6(2), as the case may be), the method in accordance with which the amount of ECPP tax attributable to the asset or liability (see sub-paragraph (6)) is to be paid, and
the amount of the ECPP tax specified under sub-paragraph (3)(b) that is to be paid in accordance with each method.

P2para.Text: But an exit charge payment plan may specify that any ECPP tax is to be paid in accordance with the standard instalment method only if—

P3para.Text: in the case of a plan entered into by a Part 1 company, the company’s ceasing to be resident in the United Kingdom is
not part of arrangements the main purpose of which, or one of the main purposes of which, is to defer the payment of any qualifying corporation tax payable by it;

in the case of a plan entered into by a Part 2 company, none of the PE qualifying events occurring during the migration accounting period, or bringing that period to an end, is part of arrangements the main purpose of which, or one of the main purposes of which, is to defer the payment of any qualifying corporation tax payable by it.

P2para.Text: The amount of ECPP tax attributable to each exit charge asset or liability is—

Para.Text: where—
“A” is the income, profits or gains arising in respect of the asset or liability in the migration accounting period by virtue of the relevant exit charge provision only,
“B” is the total income, profits or gains arising in respect of all the exit charge assets and liabilities in the migration accounting period by virtue of the exit charge provisions only, and
“T” is the ECPP tax.

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if, under an exit charge payment plan, the amount of ECPP tax attributable to any exit charge asset or liability is to be paid in accordance with the realisation method.
The plan must specify—

P3para.Text: each such asset or liability (so far as not already specified under paragraph 10(4)(a)), and
the amount of ECPP tax attributable to the asset or liability, calculated in accordance with paragraph 10(6).

P2para.Text: The plan must also include requirements as to the ongoing provision of information by the company to Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs in relation to the asset or liability.

P1group.Title: Content: additional information relating to assets and liabilities

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if, under an exit charge payment plan, the amount of ECPP tax attributable to an exit charge asset or liability is to be paid in accordance with the realisation method.
The plan must specify any additional information required by this paragraph in relation to the asset or liability.

Sub-paragraph (4) applies in the case of a financial exit charge asset or liability if, immediately after the migration accounting period, the remaining term of the loan relationship or derivative contract in question is less than 10 years.
The plan must specify, in relation to the asset or liability, how many years of the term of the loan relationship or derivative contract remain (rounded up to the nearest whole year).

Sub-paragraph (6) applies in the case of an intangible exit charge asset if, immediately after the migration accounting period, the remaining useful life of the asset for accountancy purposes is less than 10 years.
The plan must specify, in relation to the asset, how many years of the useful life of the asset remain (rounded up to the nearest whole year).
This paragraph applies if, under an exit charge payment plan, some or all of the ECPP tax is to be paid in accordance with the standard instalment method.
The amount of the ECPP tax that is to be paid in accordance with the standard instalment method is payable in 6 instalments of equal amounts as follows—

P3para.Text: the first instalment is due on the first day after the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period, and
the other 5 instalments are due one on each of the first 5 anniversaries of that day.

P2para.Text: But if a relevant event occurs, the outstanding balance of the ECPP tax that is payable in accordance with the standard instalment method is payable on the date on which the next instalment of that tax would otherwise have been due under the plan.
A “relevant event” means—

P3para.Text: the company becoming insolvent or entering into administration,
the appointment of a liquidator,
any event under the law of an EEA state outside the United Kingdom corresponding to an event specified in paragraph (a) or (b), or
the company ceasing to be resident in an EEA state and, on so ceasing, not becoming resident in any other EEA state.

P1group.Title: The realisation method: TCGA or trading stock exit charge assets

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: under an exit charge payment plan, the amount of ECPP tax attributable to an exit charge asset is to be paid in accordance with the realisation method, and
the asset is a TCGA or trading stock exit charge asset (see paragraph 3(2)(a) or 6(2)(a), as the case may be).

P2para.Text: The amount of ECPP tax attributable to the asset under paragraph 10(6) is payable in relation to whichever is the first to occur of the following events—

P3para.Text: the disposal of that asset at any time after—

P4para.Text: the company ceases to be resident in the United Kingdom (in the case of a Part 1 company), or
the occurrence of the PE qualifying event in respect of the asset (in the case of a Part 2 company),

P3para.Text: the tenth anniversary of the end of the migration accounting period, or
a relevant event (as defined in paragraph 13(4)).

P2para.Text: The date on which the amount is payable is—

P3para.Text: in a case falling within sub-paragraph (2)(a) or (b), the date of the event referred to, and
in a case falling within sub-paragraph (2)(c), the relevant date or, if that date has already passed, the next anniversary of that date.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (3)(b), “relevant date” means the first day after the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period.
Section 21(2) of the 1992 Act (part disposals of assets) applies for the purposes of sub-paragraph (2)(a) as it applies for the purposes of that Act.

Where part of an asset is disposed of at any time after the event mentioned in sub-paragraph (2)(a), the amount of ECPP tax attributable to the asset under paragraph 10(6) is to be apportioned on a just and reasonable basis for the purpose of applying this paragraph to the part of the asset disposed of and the part which remains undisposed of.

P1group.Title: The realisation method: other exit charge assets and liabilities

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies if—

P3para.Text: under an exit charge payment plan, the ECPP tax attributable to an exit charge asset or liability is to be paid in accordance with the realisation method, and
the asset or liability is—

P4para.Text: a financial exit charge asset or liability, or
an intangible exit charge asset,

P3para.Text: (see paragraph 3(2)(b) and (c) or 6(2)(b) and (c), as the case may be).

P2para.Text: The amount of ECPP tax attributable to any such asset or liability under paragraph 10(6) is payable in a number of annual instalments of equal amounts.
The number of annual instalments is—

P3para.Text: in a case where a number of years is specified in the plan in relation to the asset or liability by virtue of paragraph 12(4) or (6), that number, and
otherwise, 10.

P2para.Text: The instalments are due as follows—

P3para.Text: the first instalment is due on the first day after the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period, and
the other instalments are due one on each of the subsequent anniversaries of that day (until they are all paid).

P2para.Text: But see paragraphs 16 and 17 for circumstances in which all or part of the outstanding balance of the amount of ECPP tax attributable to the asset or liability under paragraph 10(6) (“the outstanding balance in respect of the asset or liability”) becomes payable.

P1group.Title: Outstanding balance becoming payable in full

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where the amount of ECPP tax attributable to an asset or liability under paragraph 10(6) is payable in instalments in accordance with paragraph 15.
All of the outstanding balance in respect of the asset or liability (as defined in paragraph 15(5)) is payable in accordance with sub-paragraph (3) if—

P3para.Text: a trigger event occurs in relation to the asset or liability (see sub-paragraph (4)), or
a relevant event occurs (as defined in paragraph 13(4)),

P2para.Text: before the last instalment is payable in accordance with paragraph 15.
The outstanding balance is payable—

P3para.Text: in a case falling within sub-paragraph (2)(a), on the date of the trigger event, and
in a case falling within sub-paragraph (2)(b), on the date on which the next instalment would otherwise have been due under the plan.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of this paragraph, a trigger event occurs in relation to an asset or liability if—

P3para.Text: in the case of a financial exit charge asset or liability, the company ceases to be party to the loan relationship or derivative contract in question, or
in the case of an intangible fixed asset, the asset is disposed of.

P1group.Title: Outstanding balance becoming payable in part

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: the amount of ECPP tax attributable to an asset or liability under paragraph 10(6) is payable in instalments in accordance with paragraph 15, and
a partial trigger event occurs in relation to the asset or liability (see sub-paragraph (4)) before the last instalment is payable.

P2para.Text: On the occurrence of that event, part of the outstanding balance in respect of the asset or liability (as defined in paragraph 15(5)) is payable.
The part payable under sub-paragraph (2) is so much of the outstanding balance in respect of the asset or liability as is attributable to the transaction mentioned in sub-paragraph (4)(a) or (b).
For the purposes of sub-paragraph (2), a partial trigger event occurs in relation to an asset or liability if—

P3para.Text: in the case of a financial exit charge asset or liability—

P4para.Text: there is a disposal of rights or liabilities under the loan relationship or derivative contract in question which amounts to a related transaction (as defined in section 304 or 596 of CTA 2009 as the case may be), but
the transaction does not result in the company ceasing to be party to the relationship or contract, and

P3para.Text: in the case of an intangible exit charge asset, there is a transaction which—

P4para.Text: results in a reduction in the accounting value of the asset, but
does not result in the asset ceasing to be recognised in the company’s balance sheet.

P2para.Text: Where part of the outstanding balance in respect of an asset or liability is paid in accordance with sub-paragraphs (2) and (3), the remaining instalments due under paragraph 15 in respect of the asset or liability continue to be payable so far as they relate to the remaining asset or liability (subject to paragraph 16 and this paragraph).
In sub-paragraph (5), the “remaining asset or liability” means—

P3para.Text: in a case within sub-paragraph (4)(a), the loan relationship or derivative contract as it exists following the related transaction,
in a case within sub-paragraph (4)(b), the asset as it continues to be recognised on the balance sheet following the transaction mentioned in that sub-paragraph.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of sub-paragraphs (3) and (5)—

P3para.Text: the outstanding balance in respect of the asset or liability, and
the remaining instalments due under paragraph 15 in respect of the asset or liability,

P2para.Text: are to be apportioned on a just and reasonable basis between the transaction mentioned in sub-paragraph (4)(a) or (b) and the remaining asset or liability.

In relation to an intangible exit charge asset that has no balance sheet value (or no longer has a balance sheet value), sub-paragraph (4)(b) applies as if, immediately before the transaction, it did have a balance sheet value.

P1para.Text: In Schedule 56 to FA 2009 (penalty for failure to make payments on time), in
the Table at the end of paragraph 1, after entry 6 insert—

tr.td: Amount payable under an exit charge payment plan entered into in accordance with Schedule 3ZB to TMA 1970

Para.Text: The later of—
the first day after the period of 12 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period (as defined in Part 1 or 2 of Schedule 3ZB to TMA 1970, as the case may be), and
the date on which the amount is payable under the plan.

P2para.Text: The amendments made by this Schedule are treated as having come into force on 11 December 2012 in relation to an accounting period if the relevant day, in relation to that period, falls on or after 11 December 2012.
In sub-paragraph (1) “the relevant day”, in relation to an accounting period, means the first day after the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the accounting period.

But if the relevant day falls between 11 December 2012 and 31 March 2013 (inclusive), paragraphs 1(4) and 4(3) of Schedule 3ZB to TMA 1970 (inserted by this Schedule) have effect as if, in each case, for “before the end of the period of 9 months beginning immediately after the migration accounting period” there were substituted “on or before 31 March 2013”.

TitleBlock.Title: Penalties: late filing, late payment and errors

P1group.Title: Amendments to Schedule 24 to FA 2007: penalties for errors

P2para.Text: In Schedule 24 to FA 2007 (penalties for errors), paragraph 13 (procedure: assessment) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (1)(c), after “assessed” insert “(subject to sub-paragraph (1ZB))”.
After sub-paragraph (1) insert—
Sub-paragraph (1ZB) applies where—

P3para.Text: a person is at any time liable for two or more penalties relating to PAYE returns, or for two or more penalties relating to CIS returns, and
the penalties (“the relevant penalties”) are assessed in respect of more than one tax period (“the relevant tax periods”).

P2para.Text: A notice under sub-paragraph (1) in respect of any of the relevant penalties may, instead of stating the tax period in respect of which the penalty is assessed, state the tax year or the part of a tax year to which the penalty relates.
For that purpose, a relevant penalty relates to the tax year or the part of a tax year in which the relevant tax periods fall.
For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1ZA)—

Para.Text: “a PAYE return” means a return for the purposes of PAYE regulations;
“a CIS return” means a return for the purposes of regulations under section 70(1)(a) of FA 2004 in connection with deductions on account of tax under the Construction Industry Scheme.

P1group.Title: Amendments to Schedule 55 to FA 2009: penalty for failure to make returns

P1para.Text: Schedule 55 (penalty for failure to make returns etc) to FA 2009 is amended in accordance with paragraphs 3 to 9.
In paragraph 1 (returns etc in respect of which penalties are to be paid under that Schedule)—

P3para.Text: in the definition of “penalty date” in sub-paragraph (4), after “document” insert “falling within any of items 1 to 3 and 5 to 13 in the Table”;
after sub-paragraph (4) insert—

P2para.Text: The Treasury may by order make such amendments to item 4 in the Table as they think fit in consequence of any amendment, revocation or re-enactment of the regulations mentioned in that item.

P1para.Text: In the Table at the end of paragraph 1, in item 4 (annual return of payments for purposes of PAYE regulations etc), for the words in the third column substitute—

Para.Text: Return under any of the following provisions of the Income Tax (PAYE) Regulations 2003 (S.I. 2003/2682)—
regulation 67B (real time returns)
regulation 67D (exceptions to regulation 67B)

P1para.Text: In paragraph 2 (amount of penalty: occasional returns and returns for periods of 6 months or more), for “1 to 5” substitute “1 to 3, 5”.
After paragraph 6A insert—

P1group.Title: Amount of penalty: real time information for PAYE

P1para.Text: Paragraphs 6C and 6D apply in the case of a return falling within item 4 in the Table.

P2para.Text: If P fails during a tax month to make a return on or before the filing date, P is liable to a penalty under this paragraph in respect of that month.
But this is subject to sub-paragraphs (3) and (4).
P is not liable to a penalty under this paragraph in respect of a tax month as a result of any failure to make a return on or before the filing date which occurs during the initial period.

P is not liable to a penalty under this paragraph in respect of a tax month falling in a tax year if the month is the first tax month in that tax year during which P fails to make a return on or before the filing date (disregarding for this purpose any failure which occurs during the initial period).
In sub-paragraphs (3) and (4) “the initial period” means the period which—

P3para.Text: begins with the day in the first tax year on which P is first required to make a return, and
is of such duration as is specified in regulations made by the Commissioners,

P2para.Text: and for this purpose “the first tax year” means the first tax year in which P is required to make returns.
P may be liable under this paragraph to no more than one penalty in respect of each tax month.
The penalty under this paragraph is to be calculated in accordance with regulations made by the Commissioners.
Regulations under sub-paragraph (7) may provide for a penalty under this paragraph in respect of a tax month to be calculated by reference to either or both of the following matters—

P3para.Text: the number of persons employed by P, or treated as employed by P for the purposes of PAYE regulations;
the number of previous penalties incurred by P under this paragraph in the same tax year.

P2para.Text: The Commissioners may by regulations disapply sub-paragraph (3) or (4) in such circumstances as are specified in the regulations.
If P has elected under PAYE regulations to be treated as different employers in relation to different groups of employees, this paragraph applies to P as if—

P3para.Text: in respect of each group P were a different person, and
each group constituted all of P’s employees.

P2para.Text: Regulations made by the Commissioners under this paragraph may—

P3para.Text: make different provision for different cases, and
include incidental, consequential and supplementary provision.

P2para.Text: P may be liable to one or more penalties under this paragraph in respect of extended failures.

In this paragraph an “extended failure” means a failure to make a return on or before the filing date which continues after the end of the period of 3 months beginning with the day after the filing date.
P is liable to a penalty or penalties under this paragraph if (and only if)—

P3para.Text: HMRC decide at any time that such a penalty or penalties should be payable in accordance with sub-paragraph (4) or (6), and
HMRC give notice to P specifying the date from which the penalty, or each penalty, is payable.

P2para.Text: HMRC may decide under sub-paragraph (3)(a) that a separate penalty should be payable in respect of each unpenalised extended failure in the tax year to date.
In that case the amount of the penalty in respect of each failure is 5% of any liability to make payments which would have been shown in the return in question.
HMRC may decide under sub-paragraph (3)(a) that a single penalty should be payable in respect of all the unpenalised extended failures in the tax year to date.
In that case the amount of the penalty in respect of those failures is 5% of the sum of the liabilities to make payments which would have been shown in each of the returns in question.

For the purposes of this paragraph, an extended failure is unpenalised if a penalty has not already been imposed in respect of it under this paragraph (whether in accordance with sub-paragraph (4) or (6)).
The date specified in the notice under sub-paragraph (3)(b) in relation to a penalty—

P3para.Text: may be earlier than the date on which the notice is given, but
may not be earlier than the end of the period mentioned in sub-paragraph (2) in relation to the relevant extended failure.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (9)(b) “the relevant extended failure” means—

P3para.Text: the extended failure in respect of which the penalty is payable, or
if the penalty is payable in respect of more than one extended failure (in accordance with sub-paragraph (6)), the extended failure with the latest filing date.

P1para.Text: In paragraph 18 (assessment), for sub-paragraph (5) substitute—

P2para.Text: Sub-paragraph (6) applies if—

P3para.Text: an assessment in respect of a penalty is based on a liability to tax that would have been shown in a return, and
that liability is found by HMRC to be excessive.

P2para.Text: HMRC may by notice to P amend the assessment so that it is based upon the correct amount.
An amendment under sub-paragraph (6)—

P3para.Text: does not affect when the penalty must be paid;
may be made after the last day on which the assessment in question could have been made under paragraph 19.

P2para.Text: Paragraph 19 (assessment) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (2) after “Date A is” insert

P3para.Text: in the case of an assessment of a penalty under paragraph 6C, the last day of the period of 2 years beginning with the end of the tax month in respect of which the penalty is payable,

in the case of an assessment of a penalty under paragraph 6D, the last day of the period of 2 years beginning with the filing date for the relevant extended failure (as defined in paragraph 6D(10)), and
in any other case,

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (3)(a), after “return” insert “or returns (as the case may be in relation to penalties under section 6C or 6D)”.
Paragraph 27 (interpretation) is amended as follows.
After sub-paragraph (2) insert—
The Commissioners” means the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs.
After sub-paragraph (3) insert—
Tax month” means the period beginning with the 6th day of a month and ending with the 5th day of the following month.

P1group.Title: Amendments to Schedule 56 to FA 2009: penalty for failure to make payments on time

P1para.Text: Schedule 56 (penalty for failure to make payments on time) to FA 2009 is amended in accordance with paragraphs 11 to 14.

In paragraph 1 (penalty for failure to pay tax), in sub-paragraph (4), for the words from “the date on which” to the end substitute “the day after the date specified in or for the purposes of column 4 of the Table in relation to that amount.”

P2para.Text: Paragraph 6 (amount of penalty: PAYE and CIS amounts) is amended as follows.
For sub-paragraph (1) substitute—
P is liable to a penalty under this paragraph, in relation to each tax, each time that P makes a default in relation to a tax year.
In sub-paragraph (2)—

P3para.Text: in the opening words, after “default” insert “in relation to a tax year”;
in paragraph (a), at the end insert “of tax payable in relation to the tax year”;
in paragraph (b), at the end insert “payable in relation to the tax year”;
in paragraph (c), at the end insert “payable in relation to the tax year”;
in paragraph (d), at the end insert “and due for the tax year”.

P2para.Text: For sub-paragraphs (3) to (7) substitute—

But where a failure to make one of those payments (or to pay an amount comprising two or more of those payments) would, apart from this sub-paragraph, constitute the first default in relation to a tax year, that failure does not count as a default in relation to that year for the purposes of a penalty under this paragraph.
The amount of the penalty for a default made in relation to a tax year is determined by reference to—

P3para.Text: the amount of the tax comprised in the default, and
the number of previous defaults that P has made in relation to the same tax year.

P2para.Text: If the default is P’s 1st, 2nd or 3rd default in relation to the tax year, P is liable, at the time of the default, to a penalty of 1% of the amount of tax comprised in the default.
If the default is P’s 4th, 5th or 6th default in relation to the tax year, P is liable, at the time of the default, to a penalty of 2% of the amount of tax comprised in the default.
If the default is P’s 7th, 8th or 9th default in relation to the tax year, P is liable, at the time of the default, to a penalty of 3% of the amount of tax comprised in the default.
If the default is P’s 10th or subsequent default in relation to the tax year, P is liable, at the time of the default, to a penalty of 4% of the amount of tax comprised in the default.
In sub-paragraph (8), for paragraph (b) substitute—

P3para.Text: a previous default counts for the purposes of sub-paragraphs (5) to (7A) even if it is remedied before the time of the default giving rise to the penalty.

P2para.Text: After sub-paragraph (8) insert—
Regulations made by the Commissioners for Her Majesty’s Revenue and Customs may specify—

P3para.Text: circumstances in which, for the purposes of sub-paragraph (2), a payment of less than the full amount may be treated as a payment in full;
circumstances in which sub-paragraph (3) is not to apply.

P2para.Text: Regulations under sub-paragraph (8A) may—

P3para.Text: make different provision for different cases, and
include incidental, consequential and supplementary provision.

P1para.Text: After paragraph 9 insert—

P1group.Title: Interaction with other penalties and late payment surcharges

P1para.Text: In the application of the following provisions, no account shall be taken of a penalty under this Schedule—

P3para.Text: section 97A of TMA 1970 (multiple penalties),
paragraph 12(2) of Schedule 24 to FA 2007 (interaction with other penalties), and
paragraph 15(1) of Schedule 41 to FA 2008 (interaction with other penalties).

P2para.Text: Paragraph 11 (assessment of penalty) is amended as follows.
For sub-paragraph (4A) substitute—

If an assessment in respect of a penalty is based on an amount of tax due or payable that is found by HMRC to be excessive, HMRC may by notice to P amend the assessment so that it is based upon the correct amount.
An amendment made under sub-paragraph (4A)—

P3para.Text: does not affect when the penalty must be paid;
may be made after the last day on which the assessment in question could have been made under paragraph 12.

P2para.Text: Omit sub-paragraph (5).

P1para.Text: In consequence of paragraph 7, paragraph 10 of Schedule 10 to the Finance (No. 3) Act 2010 is repealed.

P2para.Text: The amendments made by paragraph 1 have effect in relation to any assessment of a penalty under Schedule 24 to FA 2007 made on or after the day on which this Act is passed.

The amendments made by paragraphs 2 to 9 and 15 have effect for the tax year 2014-15 and subsequent tax years in relation to failures to make returns with a filing date (as defined in paragraph 1(4) of Schedule 55 to FA 2009) on or after 6 April 2014.

The amendments made by paragraphs 10 to 14 have effect for defaults made in relation to the tax year 2014-15 and subsequent tax years (see paragraph 6(2) of Sch.56 to FA 2009 (as amended by paragraph 12(3) of this Schedule) as to when a default is made in relation to a tax year).

TitleBlock.Title: Withdrawal of notice to file etc

P1para.Text: TMA 1970 is amended in accordance with paragraphs 2 to 5.

P2para.Text: Section 7 (notice of liability to income tax and capital gains tax) is amended as follows.
In subsection (1)—

P3para.Text: for paragraph (b) substitute—
falls within subsection (1A) or (1B),
for “six months from the end of that year” substitute “the notification period”.

P2para.Text: After subsection (1) insert—
A person falls within this subsection if the person has not received a notice under section 8 requiring a return for the year of assessment of the person’s total income and chargeable gains.
A person falls within this subsection if the person—

P3para.Text: has received a notice under section 8 requiring a return for the year of assessment of the person’s total income and chargeable gains, and
has received a notice under section 8B withdrawing the notice under section 8.

P2para.Text: In subsection (1) “the notification period” means—

P3para.Text: in the case of a person who falls within subsection (1A), the period of 6 months from the end of the year of assessment, or
in the case of a person who falls within subsection (1B)—

P4para.Text: the period of 6 months from the end of the year of assessment, or
the period of 30 days beginning with the day after the day on which the notice under section 8 was withdrawn,

P3para.Text: whichever ends later.

P2para.Text: In subsection (2), for the words from “shall have effect” to the end substitute “and subsections (1A) to (1C) have effect as if references to a notice under section 8 were references to a notice under section 8A.”

P1para.Text: After section 8A insert—

P1group.Title: Withdrawal by HMRC of notice under section 8 or 8A

P2para.Text: This section applies to a person who is given a notice under section 8 or 8A.
Before the end of the withdrawal period, the person may request HMRC to withdraw the notice.
But no request may be made if—

P3para.Text: the person has made a return under section 8 or 8A in pursuance of the notice under that section, or
the person has been served with notice of a determination under section 28C by virtue of the notice under section 8 or 8A having been given to the person.

P2para.Text: If, on receiving a request, HMRC decide to withdraw the notice under section 8 or 8A they must do so by giving the person a notice under this section.
A notice under this section must specify the date on which the notice under section 8 or 8A is withdrawn.
For the purposes of subsection (2) “the withdrawal period” means—

P3para.Text: the period of 2 years beginning with the end of the year of assessment to which the notice under section 8 or 8A relates, or
in exceptional circumstances, such extended period as HMRC may agree with the person.

P2para.Text: Withdrawal of a notice given to a person under section 8 or 8A in relation to a year of assessment does not prevent HMRC from giving the person a further notice under that section in relation to that year.
See paragraph 17A of Schedule 55 to FA 2009 as to the cancellation of liability to a penalty under any paragraph of that Schedule by including provision in a notice under this section.

P1para.Text: After section 12AA insert—

P1group.Title: Withdrawal by HMRC of notice under section 12AA

P2para.Text: This section applies to a partner who is required by a notice under section 12AA to deliver a return.
Before the end of the withdrawal period, the partner may request HMRC to withdraw the notice.
But no request may be made if the partner has delivered a return under section 12AA in pursuance of the notice.
If, on receiving a request, HMRC decide to withdraw the notice under section 12AA they must do so by giving the partner a notice under this section.
A notice under this section must specify the date on which the notice under section 12AA is withdrawn.
For the purposes of subsection (2) “the withdrawal period” means—

P3para.Text: in the case of a partnership which includes one or more companies, the period of 2 years beginning with the end of the period in respect of which the return under section 12AA was required by the notice under that section,
in the case of any other partnership, the period of 2 years beginning with the end of the year of assessment to which the notice under section 12AA relates, or
in the case of any partnership, such extended period as HMRC may agree with the partner in exceptional circumstances.

P2para.Text: Withdrawal of a notice under section 12AA in relation to the period in respect of which the return under that section was required or year of assessment (as the case may be) does not prevent HMRC from serving a further notice under section 12AA requiring a partner to deliver a return in relation to that period or year.
References in subsections (2) to (6) to the partner include references to a successor of the partner (see section 12AA(11)).
See paragraph 17B of Schedule 55 to FA 2009 as to the cancellation of liability to a penalty under any paragraph of that Schedule by including provision in a notice under this section.

P1para.Text: In section 59B (payment of income and capital gains tax), after subsection (4) insert—

P2para.Text: In a case in which the notice required by section 7 was given following the receipt of a notice under section 8B, subsections (3) and (4) apply as if—

P3para.Text: the reference to the notice required by section 7 were a reference to the original notice required by that section, and
the references to notice under section 8 or 8A were references to the original notice under that section.

P2para.Text: In subsection (4ZA) the references to original notices are to notices given before the notice under section 8B.
Paragraph 7 of Schedule 41 to FA 2008 (potential lost revenue in respect of failure to comply with relevant obligation) is amended as follows.
After sub-paragraph (1) insert—

In the case of an obligation under section 7 of TMA 1970 which arises by virtue of subsection (1B) of that section, the potential lost revenue is so much of any income tax or capital gains tax to which P is liable in respect of the tax year in question as is, by reason of the failure to comply with the obligation—

P3para.Text: where the period specified in subsection (1C)(b)(ii) of that section applies and ends after the relevant date, unpaid at the end of that period, or
in any other case, unpaid on the relevant date.

P2para.Text: For the purposes of sub-paragraph (1A) the relevant date is—

P3para.Text: 31 January following the tax year, or
if, after that date, HMRC refund a payment on account in respect of the tax year to P, the day after the refund is issued.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (2), after “and a tax year” insert “(not falling within sub-paragraph (1A))”.
Paragraph 3 of Schedule 53 to FA 2009 (late payment interest start date: amendments and discovery assessments etc) is amended as follows.
In sub-paragraph (3)—

P3para.Text: for “as required” substitute “in accordance with a requirement”, and
after “tax)” insert “that arose by virtue of subsection (1A) of that section”.

P2para.Text: After that sub-paragraph insert—

In the case of a person (“P”) who failed to give notice in accordance with a requirement under section 7 of TMA 1970 that arose by virtue of subsection (1B) of that section, the reference in sub-paragraph (1)(c) to an assessment which ought to have been made by P is a reference to the assessment which P would have been required to make if no notice relating to the year of assessment concerned had been withdrawn under section 8B of that Act.

P1para.Text: In Schedule 55 to that Act (penalty for failure to make returns etc), after paragraph 17 insert—

P2para.Text: This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: P is liable for a penalty under any paragraph of this Schedule in relation to a failure to make a return falling within item 1 or 2 in the Table, and
P makes a request under section 8B of TMA 1970 for HMRC to withdraw a notice under section 8 or 8A of that Act.

P2para.Text: The notice under section 8B of TMA 1970 may include provision under this paragraph cancelling liability to the penalty from the date specified in the notice.
This paragraph applies where—

P3para.Text: P is liable for a penalty under any paragraph of this Schedule in relation to a failure to make a return falling within item 3 in the Table, and
a request is made under section 12AAA of TMA 1970 for HMRC to withdraw a notice under section 12AA of that Act.

P2para.Text: The notice under section 12AAA of TMA 1970 may include provision under this paragraph cancelling liability to the penalty from the date specified in the notice.
The amendments made by this Schedule have effect—

P3para.Text: in relation to a return under section 12AA of TMA 1970 for a partnership which includes one or more companies, in respect of a return for a relevant period beginning on or after 6 April 2012, and

in relation to a return under that section for any other partnership, or a return under section 8 or 8A of that Act, in respect of a return for a year of assessment beginning on or after 6 April 2012.

P2para.Text: In sub-paragraph (1)(a), “relevant period” means a period in respect of which a return is required.
